Posted: December 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is the BEST game I've EVER played with my two boys, aged 7 and 9. A+++++ 11/10, best ever. Together we've learned about physics, gravity, centre of mass, flight, ballast, geometery, engineering, problem solving, and other great topics. As a bonus is it probably the first game my wife has shown any interest in too! It's also sparked more interest in the kids toward real-life building, and they've dusted off their lego and are often inspired to build in real life after playing.In the course of 'beating' the first island we built a number of tanks with progressively better steering and durabily, a couple flying machines including a kamakazee model, a crane, a couple cars, and a number of mostly useless but fun "prototypes." Awsome.I've found many games like this have been too complicated or been burdened by a cumbersome UI. This game perfectly strikes the balance between simplicity and complexity. The game mechanics are deep enough to stay very interesting for a long time, and simple enough that we've never been frustrated. I really hope the devs stick to this winning formula they have here and just work on content, refinements, and more building pieces.

Early Access Review
								Besiege is a physics based building game where you create all kinds of crazy medieval siege engines to complete objectives ranging from delivering wood to slaughtering sheep. You want a flying block of flamethrowers? Go for it. You want a giant trebuchet? Go for it. You want to make a p*nis? You naughty little so and so, go for it anyway.+Nice graphics and simplistic level design suit the game well+The possibilites of what you can make are endless+The sandbox mode provides a great way of creating and testing different ideas+Cheap and great value for money+Physics are pretty realistic+Variety of different mission objectives as previously mentioned+A lot of parts to choose from ranging from simple to use blocks to more complex components+The game has a very basic tutorial which forces you to learn more complex things for yourself encouraging trial and error therefore increasing play-time+Doesn't require high performance to be playable as long as you use the timescale settings-There are only fifteen missions at the moment and I can't find any timescale for them implementing all of the missions which are currently unavailable in the game-No Steamworks features-The turning mechanic doesn't feel right and is sometimes quite clunkyVerdict:8A great physics based builder that's worth the small asking price despite the current lack of content.El K.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Besiege.Man, this game. I watched a stream of it and i instantly bought it.For the first hour, i thought i was playing the game wrong. Because the game encourages creativity with your machines.Yet all i built was a block with wheels and studded with cannons.Is that at all original? Nope.Did it even work? Kinda.Was it enough for the objectives? Sometimes.Did it get wrecked? Yeap. Did it look totally awesome? Hell yeah!So far, when you start the game, you are greeted by the main menu which is basically the title of the game, an options menu and a moveable 3d model of the earth (or rather, besiege's version of the earth). Much of the parts of the globe are clickable and they correspond to a level or area in the game. When you click one, it takes you to a table top figurine looking 3d model that again you click in order to choose a level to play in. For now, ipsilon is the only playable area. There are more areas to come soon in future updates.It was a little hard to figure out how to make working siege machines but when you figure it out, those knights had better watch their backs. Aaaaaand maybe the sheep too. Yes. The sheep. They litter the fields of ipsilon and just graze there like they expect you to just leave them behind. Diabolical little critters, those sheep.Getting their blood and guts all over my nice siege machine, clogging and gumming up the works with their entrails.Clever little sheep. Clever indeed.I really like the charm of the game itself, as it reminded me a lot of crush the castle on iOS only much more expanded and you aren't limited to trebuchets. I hope the devs add more parts, more ammunition types besides the flaming ball and the bomb ball, more weapons and more customization options as well as more enemies cause crushing a ton of em under my siege machine is just plain fun.The game looks absolutely beautiful as it gives off that kind of tabletop looking vibe and the fact that your siege machine can and will take damage and you see the damage actually happening. Your siege machines have to be structurally sound otherwise your machine could break, burn or explode before you even get the chance to move the machine, kill anything, or blow up stuff.I just can't get over the tabletop feel of it. It is just so damn cool looking to me.I recommend it to anyone that likes the medieval era kind of war, anyone who likes simulations and anyone who enjoys building games. Support the devs!9 Dead sheep out of 10.Would be a 10 when they add in new stuff for sure.I hope they add goats in too.

Early Access Review
								Awesome. Just awesome. And here's why:You know when you go around on youtube and see someone play a cool game, and you're all like "OMFG I WANT THAT GAME TOO!"? Well, Besiege is one of those games, but most of those games are most fun when you didn't watch those videos, because it will spoil alot of the fun. But Besiege on the other hand, is early access, so the most of the fun has yet to come. Also can you create many, many, many different sorts of things, and thus creating almost endless joy.Now, let's get down to business.Pros;-Physxx duuude! -Wide variety of levels, also lots of room to mess around in sandbox-It's early access, and for one of such, it is quite big.-Unlimited resources-Good framerate. I mention this because my laptop can't handle much, but yet, if i keep the graphics normal, it works fine.-Fun to look at-graphics-Being indirectly able to share creations. I feel like they should be saved on Besiege's own database. My laptop broke down, and I lost everything.Cons;-No way to change objects' color-No tutorials for (for example) aviation(=flight)-No information on objects' mass-The enemies, except for the archers and the bombs, don't even touch you     -> You should have a button for this in levels with knights, so that you can make it a bit more challenging-No custom maps (yet?)-Not alot of information on what stuff does. This doesn't necessarily bother me, but for unexperienced players this will be a problem.-The basics should be explained at the 1st stage, the weaponry at the first fighting/explosive stage, and so on.Conclusion;Great game, but minor things that I expect to be updated and patched pretty soon.One of my all-time favorites 8.7/10 - Cpt. Early Access Review
								Besiege is a gem hidden among the trash that has recently come to steam, (cough cough grass simulator). A great game with good physics, beautiful graphics, a relatively easy to use building system, and overall fun gameplay. Smash sheep, splatter soldiers, or just build to your hearts content, the endless possiblities that besiege offers are simply astonishing. I am writing this review in early access, however from what I have seen so far into the game, although only being one campaign level, and a bit of a bugged sandbox, I see a game with the potential to turn into one of the best games on steam. If you enjoy a game that gives you the power to smush over affectionate sheep, create elaborate contraptions, and build practically anything, this is the game for you. Once more, a simply superb game and I hope to see it really live to its potential.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
Early Access Review
 Besiege? Where do I begin? Well, what is it? It's like Call of Duty, except less shooting and more quality. They give you the tools and the objectives, you make the epic machinery. Essentially, it's a medieval construction simulation, with some exploding sheep.How's the gameplay?I play on a really crappy laptop. Pretty sure it was handed down by my grandfather when he was a child. Anyways, this game still runs smoothly on it. I mean, when I add 124 cannons to my invention it does lag up a little, but c'mon. Who needs 124 cannons, really?The controls are very easy to learn. As long as you know how to read, you shouldn't have trouble. It falls into the category of easy to learn, but extremely difficult to master. There are literally unlimited possiblities. You just need to have the skills and the knowledge to bring out the true potential this game has.How're the graphics?Ugh. They're gorgeous.You think that literally popping enemies open, watching their guts and blood splatter all over the map as you shred their bodies to pieces with your deadly innovation, wouldn't be beautiful? Well you're wrong.Every animation, every explosion, every texture, is spot on. Definitely one of my favorite styles of graphics too: clean, organized, easy to navigate, and elegant. You see, I like to be elegant while hacking flocks of birds to pieces and sending pieces of rock from castles and monuments flying into the air. It makes me feel better about myself.Is the game buggy? And no, we're not asking you to compare it to an insect.It does have a few glitches and faults.But really, don't we all? *whoa man that's deep*Sometimes, I'll be driving along in my flame-throwing-saw-wielding-semi-flying-ten-wheeled-construction-of-destruction, and the wheels will just decide they can't even anymore, and they flip up in the air and my innocent little vehicle getting torn to pieces. By the air. That does happen. Sometimes.But the bugs certainly don't make it unplayable by any stretch. If anything, they're just funny. I'm usually too busy laughing my tonsils out to actually get annoyed at the glitches.Is it worth the price?YES. If a game costs less than the price of a sandwich at Burger King, you really can't go wrong. And Besiege does. Enough said.Does it have any replay value?Absolutely! Every level leaves you with the feeling of: 'Did I make the awesomest and most effective invention possible for that objective?' ... 'Could I have done it faster?' ... 'Could I have done it without blowing up my entire invention?' And, generally speaking, that drives you to try again, even if you've already beaten the level.So, all in all, is Besiege a good game?Good? GOOD?!?!  IS IT GOOD?!?!Lol yes.It's amazing.It's better than the meal at Burger King that costs the same amount of money, it will last you a lot more time... and heck it has less saturated fat too!And get this: it's not even done.There are only 2 areas publicly available as of yet. The second isn't even all the way done. It's in freaking Early Access. And it's this good.If you don't buy this, and by the time it's done it's an epic game that costs a lot more and has a huge fanbase, don't say I didn't call it out. Do your dietary health a favor, skip your lunch at Burger King, eat some celery instead, and buy this game. You won't regret it.~ caleb4est

								OK, so it's definitely early access.  The game is not finished, there's a campaign but only about what looks like 1/4 of it is actually built.  So what does that mean?Do you buy a game like this to play a campaign?  Probably not.  You buy it for the physics sandbox and the fun you can have trying to make the damn things fly without crashing.So, the campaign as it is, is fun, but over quick.  The great stuff is, there's an almost infinite number of ways to 'win' each mission depending on what you like to build, for example, one mission I think you're supposed to build a flying machine to kill birds, I couldn't figure out how to build one that'd work so I put a bladed windmill on a post and raised that in front of the oncoming birds and chopped them up, job's right.You'll find this game will challenge your ingenuity, like what do you do when you need an angled piece of wood?  The not so great stuff is, it's short, not always intuitive and has a reasonably steep learning curve.  If you invest into it (plus there are already a lot of youtube tutorials) you'll be rewarded.If you like to build, buy this game. Early Access Review
My regular ending of each successful missions be like:"♥♥♥♥♥ttttt, that actually worked!? In your face, medievals!"I'm not at all far into the game but the satisfactions gained from each missions straightforwardly tells me that I simply like the game. The first thing to point out is that the game has a very short tutorial at the start and it will expect you to do a bit self-learning by doing its earlier missions that are all catered for you to use various tools and weapons for your machine's design. Unlike plenty other games, this game doesn't require you to unlock a certain materials or weapons, rather everything was made available to you from the start and there is no currency in the game thus you are able to design your machine with maximum capabilities and resources. Upon knowing the available selection of materials and weapons and how they work, you are then left to your own creativity on how to accomplish a mission and it can be done in any way possible, only restricted by a maximum size of how large and wide your machine can be. Basically, this game does not have a high learning curve and it doesn't require anyone to master physics to enjoy it. The game looks and runs brilliantly. The UI is simplistic enough and you won't have to go through much exploring to get used to it. You may need to get used to the camera's movement and control at the start but I assume that is the case for any games at all. All in all, it's a great game to play from time to time and if you decide to play it, don't think too much. Blast em all on and watch the sheeps and soldiers flew and bleed to fulfill your enjoyment.Update: Updated for Steam Awards. I placed it under nomination for "Did It Work?" category under "We Didn't Think Everything".

Early Access Review
								I can't recommend this highly enough.  While you'll likely begin with a simple wooden go-cart covered in spikes/saws/drills/giant spinning blades, each level nudges you into building some new type of monstrosity, and oh, the monstrosities you shall create.  You'll build catapults, you'll build flying machines, you'll build things that look like medieval torture device carnival rides.  Your engineering failures will be massive and catastrophic, and just as much fun as the successes.The range of weapons and mechanical pieces provide plenty of options without being redundant.  The mechanical bits (hinges, springs, joints, etc.) allow for an incredible amount of freedom in design (Tip: each activated piece can have both its parameters and hotkey reassigned - e.g. to give each of two opposing springs different elasticity and make them pull separately).  Everything functions smoothly, the physics engine is excellent, and the artistic design is (subjectively) very easy on the eyes.  The Early Access aspect appears to be mainly in content, with additional levels being added over time, but also making it an absolute steal for the price.

Early Access Review
								Straight up gameplay:


YouTube™ Video: Besiege - A fun physics game! 

			Views: 1,204		

			Besieged is the perfect example of making physics entertaining. This game implements realistic physics into a medieval siege, where you build a physics based mechanism and use it against objectives...		

Besiege is a fun physics based game where you build a mechanism to destroy different objectives.The building in the game is very smooth and certainly polished as there are little to no bugs, which is suprising as it's early access. There is a wide variety of things to choose from and the ways you can build are very limitless so that creating things can be done with a lot of freedom, you can build huge moveable towers, seige engines, catapults and even flying machines!When it comes to the execution of your builds everything is physics based, your machines structure is affected by gravity and many other realistic factors, this allows you to apply common knowledge to your build and also makes it challenging and introduces this games aspect of experimentation. It is very enjoyable tweaking things around and making things work and at the same time it is quite hilarious watching some dumb builds fall over and sometimes explode. Destroying objects such as farm animals and players is quite hilarious, watching masses of bodies spinning in the air without limbs. God i'm weird. Destroying buildings is like knocking down a tower of playing blocks, and it's quite enjoyable to watch!The game is quite small but it is definately worth the price, although the base of the game is small, it seems to be a game I would personally easily spend 50 hours on!

								This is a game that I highly recommend. It's one of the few non-broken steam greenlight/early access games.The engine is beautiful and I'm really impressed by the visuals. It's a really nice toy-box kind of look that gives a kind of serenity to your slaughter. It also runs great and I have had no performance issues whatsoever. A major concern of mine that the physics engine would be broken or glitchy turned out to not be true. Everything works how you would expect it to and the consistency of the engine makes troubleshooting your designs easy. My first straight run took about 100 minutes. However, I am going to replay it many times to see just how ridiculous of contraptions I can make to complete the objectives. With some really minor improvements and expansion to the content already present, as well as levels being added eventually, this is going to be an even better game than it is now. content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
Early Access Review
Make a machine that launches projectiles only to realise the projectile will launch your machine.Besiege is crazy. You just can't help it but laugh to your heart's content once you see your elegant and complex catapult being launched instead of the rocks it was supposed to throw or your 30-cannon platform being torn to pieces due to the backfire. You will fail, my friend. But you will laugh. And then, you will try again, until you reach victory.Besiege is a physics-building hybrid, where you construct elaborate war machines with the objective to clear each stage. Anything that comes to your mind, you can craft it: from old-fashioned trebuchets and helicopters to tanks with windmill-like contraptions that maul your foes and needle-armored cars. Your imagination is the limit, and you will spend many hours building the weirdest machines you can imagine. Engineering in Besiege is simply beautiful. Just like Lego, you snap together blocks, wheels, pistons, weapons and many, many more while praying your machine is gonna work, let alone move. Following trial and error, you will imrpove your machines or build new ones. The way to realise your goals has many paths, and you are free to follow the one that suits your imaginations. The best thing you can do, and I strongly reccomend it, is search on the internet for ideas. I have seen (and built) flying machines that can carpet bomb the entire map, catapults that self-reload, transforming robots and more. Before you grasp the basics of this game, it's worth trying to follow some guides and build some other hilarious and crazy stuff first.When trying to complete objectives, keep in mind there's a limit in size to what you can build. However, the free-build mode allows you to alter the game's objectives and make your own, allowing you to go as big and wild as you want.In story mode, things are simple: you got a build phase, where time is stopped for you to build your machine, and action phase, where you witness you machine in action as your enemy's troops are trying to destroy it. You can swap between phases as often as you like, something really useful for your experimentation.On the downside, there's not an actual story to follow which is not a bad thing. The music gets a bit monotonous at times, and it would be nice to see some extra graphic features added, like more grass, buildings and trees, since mostly the objectives are present in your map.As an early access game, I absolutely reccomend you grab it. Although there are not many campaign stages, its toy box and free build features are unrivalled: you can make the biggest, meanest, and most hilarious war machine and watch it destroy a tiny village full of men and sheep. It feels pretty close to completion than other titles, and I have the feeling it's gonna be big when the full version will be released.RATING:Gameplay: 8.5/10Presentation: 7.5/10Enjoyment (replacing story): 8/10Unique Factor: Engineering Freedom: 9.5/10OVERALL: 8.3/10

Posted: January 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								*THIS GAME IS EARLY ACCESS*Therefore alot is not available, currently only a makeshift sandbox world and 1 continent with 15 levels that can be replayed over and over.First off, this game is beautiful. The maps, the displays, UI, physics; just all beautiful.I had difficulty in the start because all my cannons would fire at once or my contraption would snap from tension and being to rigid and thats when I realized that this is not just some clicking simulation, no sir. You need to account for torque, being too rigid, weight, moveability, wheels snapping, key mapping, or even just being a big rubberband of wood and wires...Once you have a stable block of wood that doesnt crumble or self destruct you can add some weapons like cannons or flamethrowers or spikes. Now you don't want all your cannons going off at once since its a one shot weapon so you'll have to change some key mapping for those. Oh right, lets not forget; every action there is reaction, so if you have a weapon on a flimsy limb the force can snap it off...So after meddling with things maybe you want to head to sandbox (if you're not already there) and try building ballistas' or catapults, all capable with the handy dandy wire thingy that lets you quickly expand/contract it like a rubber band. Or there are these things called pistons that expand/contract themselves into smaller/larger blocks. There are so many possibilities right now it's crazy.Tired of being on the ground? you can make a FREAKING AIRPLANE. No jokes. Being an early access there are some bad things of course.a) Trying to change item when building can spawn one at that spot of clicking instead of changing items (not often, mostly sandbox)b) The amount of levels is pretty slim but other continents are already laid out for future updatesc) Enemies are slim variety; but as with (b) I'm expecting more as it progresses!Usually these early access games can cost you an arm and a leg but this one is pretty dirt cheap in comparison and is a ton of fun. If you reaaally don't want to scringe on $7ish and you ever see it on sale, you go buy the crap out of it.I'm expecting great things from this game; hopefully workshop compatibility, more items/enemies, gamemodes. I don't think I can stress this enough though, this is early access so its missing alot yes, there are a few minor problems yes, but is this still a great game currently? yes.I thoroughly am enjoying this game. 9.5/10

Early Access Review
"Besiege" ReviewBesiege is a fantastic sandbox build it-and-break it game that should be an integral part of everyone's library. As one of my personal picks, I'd easily recommend it to anyone. Objective In Besiege, you must create vehicles and weapons to conquer various zones and regions. This includes killing soldiers and sheep, breaking down citadel walls, and crushing obstacles. You have the freedom to add huge weaponized structures, propellers, armor, wheels, and more to absolutely anything you can think of. You can save and load anything from your previous creations or from workshop creations, as long as it fits in a certain size box in order to progress to the next level. Levels are fairly simple, but with the countless ways to build, the most important aspect is not just completing objectives. Audio, Graphics, and Performance I would recommend running Besiege on at least a GTX 750Ti or AMD equivalent, as it is very graphics-intensive on the best settings. There are weather and wind effects which are fairly taxing on your system. On a laptop, the game ran pretty hot, but on a GTX 860M it did run well. On Intel Integrated Graphics, expect a range from 5-25 fps. It looks phenomenal, and fire/water have very nice particle effects. Value 7 bucks for a Early Access game with very regular updates, huge amounts of workshop content, and a very supportive community behind it... wait, 7 bucks? This game is a must buy. Absolute must buy. Despite the name and how it may insinuate some undesirable copycat rpg, it's not. It's Minecraft on steroids, it's Blockstorm on crack. Besiege, although it is in Early Access and has limited story mode content, has a sandbox mode which will undoubtedly provide every user hours of gameplay beyond any form of organized content it can provide. With the aforementioned workshop content, you can install mods, custom vehicles, even community concepts from movies.AspectRatingOriginality10Graphics10+Audio10Value10Overall10 Final Points on the Game An absolutely stunning graphics engine, phenomenal sound effects, and a new take on build 'n' smash makes Besiege one of my personal picks.Be sure to check out any of my other reviews on my profile, and please upvote if this helped you, I hope it did! Thanks for reading!If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

Early Access Review
								Excellent game, especially for the current price (7 USD), though once they add more levels, it'd easily be worth double that. Though at the time of writing this review, the game does suffer from some minor problems due to it being early access. The game itself is fun, engaging, and challanging. It's a unique experience at full of replayability.The objectives are simple enough. Currently you will either be asked to destroy something, move something, or go to something. The levels are also simple and clean, much like the (very attractive, though still simple) graphics. In fact, the entire game is only about 100 megs, which for a full 3d game with this much dynamic content, says a lot about how much the developer(s) care about keeping it efficient. The interface is a little bit more complicated, but only because of the inherint complexity of building things.And this is where the game really shines, with building things. There are only about 40 parts, at a guess, but with them you can build pretty much anything you set your mind to, so long as you aren't too ridiculous. Catapults and go-carts are only the tip of the iceburg. Build a machine gun! A helicopter! A transformer! The only limit is your imagination and you mechanical prowess. After beating all the currently available levels (about 15, at another guess), I had the urge to go play them again, but differently, and possibly with self-imposed challanges like 'no wheels'. I doubt that the game will give you hundreds of hours of playtime, but it will deliver nigh-unrivaled entertainment (and potentially, challange!) in a much more compact package than most games these days. The only real problem I can see someone having is if they are extremely impatient and easily frustrated. A friend of mine who is a little impatient enjoys the game, but if you're the type who mashes buttons and yells at your computer, well, we don't need you, but you're probably on a console anyway.

Early Access Review
								13 / 10, would mechanically eviscerate an artful creation in a terrifying, uncontrollable trundle, ending in a deafening blast again.  Actually, right now.Why haven't you bought this game yet?!  It's like all the violence you always wanted out of your lego/erector kit, with none of the "What happened to the neighbors' RV and where is the lawnmower??"awkwardness.  Sorry, dad, I was actually aiming for the boat.This is not a physical /simulation/ in the strictest sense, but I sure have burned and bombed and flown and driven and chopped and sliced and dropped and spun quite enough to be duly impressed with the engine.  Looking forward to the Unity 5 build!PROS!- Blow stuff up!- Drive over your enemies.- Slice through your enemies.- Whirr violently.- Crash and die in a fireball of glory from oversteering.- Flexibility and control, like Lego and ErectorCONS?- Your imagination might not be awesome enough.  Start besieging and give it a workout!- Blow yourself up!  Over and over and over!  (may not be an actual con)- Early access, which is also not necessarily a con, just a warning that if you want to 'beat' the official content part of the game, it won't take too long.  But that's not why you're here, is it?  No, you're here for glory and blood, and likes and votes on your favorite online community.PROSEA couple details I've noticed - stacking motorized wheels in the same rotational direction compounds rotational velocity, and this is great fun for creating massive lift in a high-speed rotating wing.  If you're building a quad copter with proper rotors (vice the tiny flying screws), flip the opposite corner wheels and blades - the torsion in one direction from the NE/SW pair will offset that of the NW/SE pair and provide tons of lift for massive cargo capacity with a gentle lilt for airborne control.  And you can easily get enough kit into the legal bounding box to build a total Ipsilon conquerer.Remember, every action has an equal and opposite reaction, more or less.  That thing you're spinning is pushing forward against the mass to which is attached, which is likewise pulling backward, y'know, relatively.  Don't forget your swivel joints, and try not to rip yourself a new axle.Get used to using a keyboard!  Every control is assignable - imagine doing all these things: releasing bombs, firing cannons, moving forward/back/up/down/left/right, igniting/extinguishing flamethrowers, pulling springs, turning gears, steering, flapping, et cetera ad infinitum.  Now imagine doing them all in multiple sets.  Yeah, you're going to need all of the 101+ on that keyboard for your ulimate besiegery monster.I look forward to a standardized best-practice sort of control scheme from the community, similar to the WASD standard nowadays.My wishlist -Fluid dynamics - air, water, and fuel, with related containers, pumps, dispersion... volatility [daisy cutter, anyone?]Micro- and mega- parts, or adjustable (stepped) scale for existing parts.Use the standard bounding box for 'normal' difficulty, but add a larger size for 'medium' and larger still for 'easy', which would still allow level advancement (but forfeit street cred, you lamer).  Or a smaller box for 'hardcore' difficulty.Paint, Colors, Decals!The moon and low gravity glory!I'm off now, to test out an idea with some sliders and create a proper DoomTrain.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								When speaking of an Early Access title on Steam it is important to note that development is not yet done.  Any comments here about bugs and design issues may have been corrected in an update after this Review has been posted.  Please consider the posting date before using this as a gauge on the quality of the title being looked at.A physics-based sandbox wherein users are encouraged to create their own war machines using a series of simple mechanical devices; Spiderling Studios' Besiege lets users' creativity run wild with how to be the most destructive and does so beautifully.While Early Access and Kickstarter began as a way for users to help shape the future of games it has quickly degraded into a way for developers to get a quick cash-in that leaves half-baked messes in end-users' laps.  Titles like Double Fine's Spacebase DF-9 and Broken Age are examples of how to take people's money and give them less than what they paid for in return.  Developers like Double Fine abandon games like Spacebase DF-9 only half completed and missing all the promised depth and challenge.  Besiege, by having promised little more than the ability to make your favourite doomsday device and giving a great deal of mechanics that users can use in any way, has already surpassed my expectations wildly.At this stage in development Besiege has two game modes: Sandbox and Campaign.  Sandbox sets the player in a space filled with many things to destroy and interact with but no explicit goal.  Campaign however sets the player in a much smaller field with the need to build their war machine to fulfill a specific goal.  Players can be tasked with destroying a castle or village, navigating a minefield to reach a specific point, killing an army, or several things at once.Just as with Garry's Mod or the Kerbal Space Program, Besiege gives players the ability to do whatever they want and rewards them with an entertaining if not always expected result.  The Internet is already filled with screenshots by more creative users that show off flying cities, walking automatons, and dune buggies.  The limits of ones imagination are really the biggest thing in a player's way.Spinning bladed death platforms like in the BBC's Robot Wars television series are easy to make, sending streams of blood everywhere as soldiers are rend limb from virtual limb.  You can make ornithopters, helicopters, blimps - it is truly a wonder to find yourself creating a machine to drop a series of flamethrowing platforms on people.Graphically Besiege takes a light, cartoonish feel while at the same time providing pools, spurts, splashes and mists of blood when killing enemies and innocents via the games many weapons.  Fire and explosion effects give a pseudo-realistic spread and additional destruction that can help and hurt the player's plans.And then there is the physics.  Besiege's physics take my not entirely useless PC and make it grind to a halt at times.  The more complex you build your war machine, the slower the results will play out.  This of course will be improved by the team at Spiderling Studios as the game continues to grow and take shape, but it can be quite annoying now when you make your bomber rise into the air to drop its payload of flaming bombs and time begins to slow.Developers are presently looking to refine their physics and add more weapons and mechanics in addition to completing upcoming game modes like the heretofore mysterious Moon, which Spiderling Studios have yet to give concrete details on, but may end up with new physics and enemies to play with.  And where the current campaign mode is just a single continent they are working on an additional four campaigns in order to progress to global domination, and it would be great if with these new continents came new art styles and enemy behaviour.  Where the current continent campaign of Ipsilon is strictly European, perhaps Phi will end up Chinese, Persian, or Indian.  And it would be a nice way to spice up the game were the dev team to introduce a map maker and integrate Steam Workshop for sharing of challenges.  There is a world of potential that Spiderling can bring to the game.Even as a staunch opponent of Pre-ordering and Early Access purchases - by promising little and giving users a great many ways to do it Besiege has won me over.  If you want a quick laugh as you accidentally blow yourself up, or a challenging interactive puzzle game, you will not be disappointed with this Early Access title.  At 7 dollars, this game is a steal for any creative-types out there.

								I super, super much recommend Besiege but let's start with obvious disclaimers anyway: Besiege is still early access. I sometimes see people forgetting this and getting stupidly angry. I remember seeing some gifs of some early creations many years ago, drooling in envy because I thought I could never do something like that. Then I started playing and the (completely optional) campaign missions did a good job coaching me to try new things and I am constantly coming up with new ideas of what to do.Especially with some (easy-to-install) mods that expand the available building tools Besiege becomes a really powerful and fun physics toy.Only limit on your creativity is your available CPU power, and that is one part where the early access shows. content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								A lot of people including myself have been burned by some early access game, so naturally I was a little sketical about purchasing it. I can't resist the demolition and bridge builder style of flash games, so I really couldn't help but get it. For $7.79 it's hard to say no anyways.The game on a whole is very slick. The graphics are very smooth and easy on the eyes, minimalistic. but in such a way that looks very proffesional. The pictures on the store page look cinematic, something you wouldn't expect to find in the game, but it's almost the exact same in game, no added filters to glam it up, the game really does look good. You won't find pictures of it, but the in game menus are stunning, really clean and incredibly proffesional looking.The gameplay is absurdly fun. You can do pretty much whatever you like and beat the level a hundred different ways. In one of the first levels you destory a small building. You can destory it with a few blocks and some wheels. Or you can create a trebuchet with 78 Cannons attached and 37 flame throwers. If that doesn't tickle your fancy you can make an plane loaded with half a dozen massive bombs and drop them over the tiny house, or just fly right into it.Tonnes of fun, you can easily spend half an hour building just one machine.Pros:-Cheap-Good graphics-Really fun-Good for a quick game-Good for long game-Can play a level over and over-Minimal bugsCons:-Not much for levels right now-Controls can sometimes feel a little weird-Could use a bit more variety in blocks-Still has some bugs (expected, usually hilarious)Overall, for an early access game, 9/10Compared to most early access, 11/10.There seems to be a lot of stuff on the way, and a lot of it is also there as "Coming soon", so you can get idea of what is to come as well (like playing on the moon).

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Besiege is an early access, simulation game from Spiderling Studios. Let’s get rocking.The GoodHave you ever wanted to create gigantic machines with the sole purposes of wreaking havoc, taking life, and racking up an outrageous amount of property damage? Did you answer yes? If, so, you should probably get some help…or just get Besiege and live out those homicidal fantasies of yours in the game.If you can dream it, you can build it. Granted, your dreams will be limited by the amount of materials given to you in the game for use in the construction of aforementioned death machines, but, if you take a look at the Steam Workshop, you’ll see that there isn’t much of a limit as to what you can build here.Once you get the hang of how things work, you’ll find yourself spending in inordinate amount of time playing this game. It’s a solid time killer and quite a lot of fun.The BadThe font in the game is incredibly small. Maybe that’s just at my resolution, but I don’t know.The MehSometimes the physics in the game don’t work like you’d expect physics to work in real life. It doesn’t come up often, but it does come up.It’s still in early access, so, there’s not much to do besides a short “campaign” and messing around in the sandbox.Verdict: YeaIf you have a deep love for both creation and destruction and you can’t keep those voices quiet in your head, this just might be the game for you. Seriously though, it’s a fun game and if you have the cash, you shouldn’t hesitate to add it to your collection.

Early Access Review
								Besiege isn't really a BAD game. What's there is actually very solid, especially for an Early Access game. The visuals are beautiful, the gameplay is entertaining and well put together, and the whole thing is all quite fun............for about 5 minutes.You see, Besiege's biggest problem is that, well, there's just not a whole lot to do. Thanks to this being an Early Access game, there are only about 20 levels or so in the main "story" mode, with the devs promising to add more later on.Almost all of these levels revolve around destroying something, with occasional breaks to grab something and deliver it somewhere, or get to a certain point in the map or whatever. While entertaning at first, these levels quickly become repetitive (at least for me) and lose their charm after the first few stages. You can go to the sandbox and screw around with making ridiculous, absurd contraptions, but this also gets very dull very quickly.Bottom line:    Besiege has all the trappings of a fantastic game. It is just brimming with potential, and IF the devs stick with it, it could become something truly special. For now, though, Besiege just doesn't have enough content. I would recommend waiting until they finish the game before you decide to buy it.*EDIT*Since this is an Early Access game, it is always updating and adding new content. Thus, as more and more stuff is added, this review becomes more and more outdated.However, I believe that my message still stands. Be wary and be smart. Besiege is simply too lacking in things to do at this point, and that will certainly change over time.Once (or if) the game exits Early Access, I will re-review it. I'm sure that by that point it will be pretty awesome.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I absolutely love this game to death, as it is fun, and so creative for a kid like me with a huge imagination.It does have just a few downsides...1. The lag.The lag is a problem due to many entities moving at once. This is not the greatest for low-end computers. I have a computer with 6GB of RAM and a 1GB GPU, and an iMac with 4GB of RAM and a 128MB GPU. They both run the game fine with small items, but builds with around 100+ blocks lag the computer and start decreasing the framerate dramatically. I would recommend a non-attatched entity remover built into the game. Cannonballs are an example for this. With one of the newer updates, we were intoduced to the Infinite Ammo option, allowing you to spam cannons. There are so many cannonballs not removed that it will start lagging the system trying to calculate all of those entities.2. ControlsDon't get me wrong, but the controls are fine, but in some ways, they are sorta on the "eh" side. Placing braces or blocks are an example. The game will make it move to an undesired location, making you have to remove the block. (That's pretty much it for this.)3. Semi-glitchy GameplayThe gameplay is amazing, and sometimes, the glitches are funny as hell, but shaking is something most of us with 30+ hours in the game have noticed. I have made creations that are amazing, and out of nowhere, it will start shaking insanely and throw the entire creation into pieces. I don't know why it happens, but it will need to be fixed in the future. It can get really annoying. Another way of glitching in Besiege is some blocks get caught on other blocks. I have only experienced this a few times, and it isn't that big of a deal, but when you are trying to fling a bomb at a tower and it explodes in your face, that can be a problem.Anyway, this is just a review in the Early Access time. In future updates, everything will more than likely be fixed. This is NOT to turn away people from buying this game, as it is an absolute rollercoaster of creativity at your fingertips. I would HIGHLY recommend this game for anyone with an extremely creative mind, such as myself.10/10. I will play this game until the end of time.

								Not a bad game at all. Not going in my play everyday file, but it is engrossing. It is entertaining. It is hairpulling.. :-p Start with a blank brain for any ideas. Little infantrymen, archers, stone castles.. and even things that challenge beyond that. Bombs and tanktraps.. even floating places that require aviation ( I ve not gotten there yet )Think of it like SE meets ME minus any survival resouce gathering and not doing it cheating or in an edit mode.. because the challenges make up for the other bits. Now, if your a wiz at engineering, or at understanding how to design aircraft out of bubblegum and a few sticks.. your probably not going to be as entertained.. but for a zero engineering mind like me.. its great!!! The really really good building types are putting out workshop items that defy belief. M1A1 tanks.. jets..  its fascinating... me.. I am still trying to figure out how to make a catapult work. 								BesiegeAbsolutely brilliant game! This is one of my favourite games in steam for sure. There is nothing like this in steam right now, it's different in many ways compared other games similar to this, one of those things is being the best.It's a very strategic game with some elements of anger when you can not get past levels. Highly recommended. If you enjoy making puzzles and challenging yourself, this is deffinnedly a must have for you! Levels are not too hard but not too easy to complete. Ofc this depends how good you are, but it's from my perspective.This game has so much blocks etc in it, you will spend some thime trying to understant what they all do, but you will learn them pretty easily. The community also offers a lot of guides and tips to help other players, that is also a big plus for this game. You can also download some cool vehicles that other people have made and belive me when I say this: there are a lot of pretty interesting and cool things that you can download.  There's a very nicely done campaign with many and many levels. There is many "islands" as I like to call them that have the levels to play trough. This game has allready good amount of levels and in the future there will be lot more to come. There is also a "moon" which sounds extremely great! Overall, brilliant game with great physics and a beautiful style that only this has! My grade for this game 9/10

Posted: March 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is one of those rare games where trial and error is more entertaining than actually passing the mission. The game's only constraints are the current number of block types available and the bounding lines for your creation (which can be shut off in sandbox mode.)My only complaints for the game (still in alpha atm, of course):Number one is the camera. It's horrible right now, forcing you to look at very odd angles to see something. A problem that is compounded when testing your contraption in combat. You can't zoom in on a certain point, but rather at the center point of the creation box.The game can quickly bog down your computer on some levels, the framerate plummeting as an entire group of soldiers goes from alive to blood smear without the in-between animation.The music, minor but still an issue, quickly gets annoying. It sounds like "No Particular Place To Go" and I can only take so much Chuck Berry when the same two lines of a song play through my head as I'm trying to kill. I'm sure it's just me and shows I'm only nitpicking as the mute button works just as well on here as it does on ads.One thing that is worth noting is the lack of a tutorial. This game is fine with starting you out with nothing as the first few missions are only testing beds and have no risk but challenge you to add onto your initial creations. But a tutorial for basic designs (or starting with a few simple designs) would have been helpful. Learning what use a few blocks have or how to make the most of other blocks would be useful as well. Otherwise, there's always youtube and the trial and error process.The graphics are wildly entertaining and makes me feel like I'm tearing through the glass villages my mother used to set up during the winter. Which actually makes it far more satisfying. Your creation has no limits at all to what you want to put on it, BUT keep in mind that weight is a huge part of this physics engine and your "liberator" can break apart under its own weight.The only thing I'd say is that in its current state the price is on par for a large game. Meaning you are spending more on this than you would for a phone app of the same content. Worth the price but will only be giving you new stuff for about two hours upon which time you will need to replay missions with impractical contraptions. However, the main menu shows that LOTS of stuff is still planned for the future.

Early Access Review
								I have seen a lot of Besiege screenshots, clips and gifs of brutal warmachines on the internet lately. I became pretty curious about this game, and thought: Why not? I am not disappointed about my purchase. Time flies by when building these machines. And the interesting thing is: you don't have to build a war machine in every level. Sometimes you just need to build a vehicle to complete a level. You can be creative in the things you build and how you want to complete the levels.And it is not always easy to build a good working machine. Sometimes you find out that the construction is not strong enough and the machine falls apart. Or maybe you find out that you had to use other weapons to destroy something.If you just want to build machines without any limits and see how they work, you can play it in the sandbox mode, which gives you a lot more freedom.The graphics are simple and cartoony, but they still look nice and pretty.  The UI is simple but also very clear. There are also a few tutorials about the very basics, but later you have to find out how you build something. Although this is an Early Access game, I think it is a good one so far. It is not finished yet, they add more building parts in updates.  And there is yet one zone with 16 levels to complete, but here are more to come in the future. And I am looking forward to the new levels to complete.My rating for this game: 8/10.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Besiege, Besiege, Besiege.When I first saw this little indie game, I was intrigued. I've always loved building mecanical creations, both in games and with tools (lots of LEGO). So when I picked it up about six months ago (for only $6.00!) I instantly had to try it out.The game (as many people can tell you) is a physics-based sandbox puzzle game. You build things to complete a set objective, and then you fail at it twenty times, tweaking it repeatedly until you get that "Aha!" moment, find something that works, and complete the level. At the time of this review, there are about 35 separate levels between two areas, with more on the way. Each level objective varies from stage to stage. Some will just require you to destroy things, while others require more precision, such as the level "Diom Well", where you need to get poison barrels into a well.The levels, however, are not the key part of this game. That would be the sandbox area and the ability to build machines of mammoth proportions. In this area, you are given the freedom to build anything you desire, ranging from giant mechs to light aircraft. It was the moment I built a giant trebuchet that made me love this game.Don't get me wrong, this game is NOT perfect. Some of the levels can be quite annoying ("Village of Diom" can die in a fire for all I care) and the mechanics for flight are very cumbersome.But for its faults, there are plenty of redeeming qualitites that lead me to recommend Besiege to someone-if they have a creative mind. That is the key factor to whether or not you will enjoy this game. If you are not a very creative person...then this is definitely not the game for you. Besiege's levels require someone to think outside of the box to complete them. And any enjoyment of the sandbox solely depends on your creativity.So, yes, I do recommend Besiege. The game is not that expensive at the time of this review ($8.00) so even if you don't like the game it didn't cost that much in the first place. (And refunds exist for a reason...) But this is one game that will stay in my library for years to come.

Posted: April 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								This was the most fun and well made Alpha build of a game I ever played!At first you may go for simple machines to go through the levels and you'll finish the game quite fast... But it's not the ammount of levels that matter in this game! It's the ammount of different machines and creation you can construct to pass those levels!You won't get bored of playing the levels over and over again because they'll never be the same! Today you may build a catapult, tomorrow a hammer, the next day a freaking helicopter!!All I have to say is, for this cheap, this game has more content and stuff to do than many other games out there that cost twice as much or more...Now, I'm no game critic nor am I quite the game connoisseur, but if someone asked me I'd rate the game as follows:Gameplay: 8/10 - because if you don't put some effort and thinking into it, chance is, it'll be a simple and possibly clunky machine.Desgin: 9/10 - Actually I'm not giving a 10/10 because my 10 goes for reallistic graphics, but this is a different realm, and the style is amazing and I wouldn't change it a bit!Level design: 8/10 - They're simple and straight forward. That's the best and the worst of it. I'd like to see some more intricate levels and I'd love to see community made maps (if that hasn't been implemented yet)Community creations: 10/10 - I love games where the community can share their work and this game allows it by letting people use others machines blueprint files, and it's as easy as copy pasta :PAnd believe me, I've seen some amazing creations. They're just incredible!Last, but definetly not least...Fun: 8/10 - You can replay this game over and over again and you'll want to go back to it as soon as you close it!"But why just 8?", you might ask... Well... As mentioned above, you'll have to put time, effort, and thought into your creations, and TO ME, not being able to be objective in a game, makes it less fun at times - with this I mean I'M LAZY AND I CAN'T BE BOTHERED TO THINK AND BUILD SOMETHING. It's not the game. It's me xDFinal score - 8/10 for all the above reasons.Remember, I'm not a game critic nor connoisseur. I'm just giving you my 2 cents and also remember that your experience and opinions may vary.Lasly, I just want to say that this game is awesome, and you should buy it! It's not expensive AT ALL and you'll be happy to have and play it.

Early Access Review
								This game is fantastic, an engineer's playground. You don't technically have to be an engineer to enjoy it, though; I'm not and I still have a blast playing it. It's a great casual game to screw around with and laugh at with friends. If you have seven dollars and an hour to kill, buy it. If you have seven dollars and several weeks worth of hours to kill, buy it. It never gets old better than Tuck Everlasting. If a developer is reading this, here are two suggestions: one, a way to implement players creating their own levels would be so neat if you could somehow pull off the objectives, just a thought, and two, this is really more of a bug fix: the dead bodies and knocked over trees are often the cause of a failure, as a machine will be stuck  on a body and fall apart, so I recommend what I call a two hit system: on the first time a person is killed or a tree is knocked over, they behave as they normally do. The second time a machine hits it hard enough to cause the first hit's result, the object explodes into a particle effect and is gone. This will get bodies out of the way and prevent ruined sessions because a wheel hit a soldier's body and shattered like glass.

Early Access Review
								Besiege essentially boils down to this, you get building blocks and using these blocks you make siege engines, flying contraptions and doomsday machines and are tasked to destroy or steal some object, or kill some people or some poor, defenseless, innocent sheep (allegedly innocent that is, you can see that murderous posture they have in their grazing, ready to strike in a moments notice). It is a game that can be played simply with a bare minimum degree of complexity and with trial or error, or with a high degree of complexity and engineering for you to perfectly craft the siege machine of your dreams. Aesthetically the game is beautiful, as it takes its models and object design from what I could only describe as very Leonardo da Vinci, giving this game a very Renaissance feel to it. Gameplay wise it is very engaging and fun to play if you're into building contraptions, and could be appropriately described as a more complex angry birds. Overall I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys puzzles in which the solution is open ended and up to you.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is good. Let me start with that. If you want a game where you're (mostly) only limited by creativity, this is a game for you. If you want a game where you can build a helecopter and watch it drop bombs on an unsuspecting village in slow motion, with burning sheep flying across this sky, this is a game for you. And if you like to sit and ponder how you could make other people's creations better, by trying to design a mechanical auto-stabalizing gyroscope this is a game for you (I couldn't :c).Pros:**+You can build pretty much anything within the scope of your medieval siege engine fantasies.+Its being updated (usually) monthly.+Good community constantly creating and designing new things, and the modding scene is good.+Once you've played it through and destroyed all the levels with your machines whose main directive is to flail until the objective is complete you can put everything you've learned to the test and build something that can actually intentionally complete the objective each time.+Once you're bored with creating machines to beat the main levels (Happened for me at around 50 hours) you can build machines in the sandbox with no objective. This leads to some things, like aircraft and helecoptors, which originally were basically useless but became much more useful when flying levels were added. +At time of writing its £4.99 or your regional equivilent. Thats rediculous. I would still recommend this if it was three times the price, maybe no more than that because of it being quite early in development and I wouldn't be able to justify the price tag, but currently its wonderfully cheap.+One thing I personally enjoy is the 'Scribblenaut' feel to it. You can solve a level in a million different ways. Some will be efficient. Some not. But its going to be your way. Thats a good feeling.+Another thing is that due to the control scheme rotations are only possible by 90 degrees in a specific plane on blocks. This means things fit together like lego. You can, however, get a mod which allows you to rotate blocks in any direction by any angle. When you're done playing with your lego, it can transform into Kinex and you get a whole new set of possiblities.Cons:-Currently there isn't that many levels or that much raw content.* I set this as a con, but it does show the game is good in its own way, because what they've done with the content allows you to make it last so much longer than you think.-The sheep. Boom.-Its in early access.* Again, this is more of a conditional negative. Its in early access and I believe it will one day release and that day will be beautiful. Until then theres always the danger that its dropped. Again, I don't think that will happen, but its possible.-The yaks. Boom.-I have to pad this list out to make me seem unbiased at a glance. And thats a good thing.**-It is glitchy. ** This may be the first real negative. Its really glitchy and there are issues with the physics and things. I don't think this will change due to the fact Im realistic. Few things are game-breaking issues and you can work around/with the glitches, but its still glitchy.-There are a few editor issues.* You cant copy/paste blocks or sets of blocks. You can't move a block once its placed, you have to delete it and replace one. The menu is easy to use and non-intrustive, but if you're building something with lots of different pieces sometimes it can get tedious.TLDR; If you're trying to decide if you should buy it or not and you're able to afford it, buy it... Just stay away from the animals.Signed - A totally unbiased fan.Baa.* I believe this applies ONLY to the build of the game on September 3rd 2015 and I believe will be changed in the future.** I DONT believe this applies ONLY to the build of the game on September 3rd 2015 and I DO NOT believe will be changed in the future.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								tl;dr Quite fun and bloody game about building dextructive medieval "things" and destroing stuff with it, however there are little levels - as of yet.Gameplay:First off, you can build your dream vehicle, tank, driveable catapult, whatever you can imagine. Then, when you hit "play", it's your job to fullfill a task given, for example killing sheep or warriors. Another common task is to destroy a building. That's pretty much the gameplay, nothing more to say. The longer you experiment, the more effectiv your builds become and the faster you can finish the level.9/10 by now, it's a hell lot of fun for a that simple game!Parts:As of yet, there are not that many parts in the game. However, I'm sure that more will be added soon, also, the little variety at the moment already makes for a large diversity of buildings/vehicles/...6/10 by nowGraphics:I personally like the graphics, they're little details and it looks quite empty, but the important things are clearly visible. Additionally, the art-style of the game is very appealing to me. It looks identical to the screenshots on the official page and the Steam-page, so if you enjoy those you will enjoy the graphics ingame aswell. What I don't like, though, is that the focus is somehow strange, it's extremely blurry pretty much everywhere on the screen except for some little parts. I didn't find an option where to correct this, but I didn't spend much time in the option menu aswell, so this might aswell be able to being turned off.8/10, without the strange blurry effects it'd be a 10/10, subjectivelyLevels:There aren't many as of yet, I finished the available ones in 2.3 hours, however, I experimented quite a bit already. I will surely put more time into the game, as I want to finish the levels better and more effective. You can somehow guess from the menu that the game will have around 6 times the content when it's finished, so roughly 15 hours I'd say. For 7€ at the moment this is quite good, others give away 30 minutes of DLC-content for 15€. Also, there's a sandbox mode soon, so there'll be loads of more content in the future, even without the devs working on more.4/10 by nowAI:The AI is simply doing what you think it'd do (except for sheeps). Normal villagers run around when they spot your vecicle, archers shoot arrows at you, the knights simply run for you and the sheep... they run directly into your vehicle or just walk around in a little area. Nothing more. If you have spikes on your vehicle you can pretty much enjoy them killing themselfs. :P11/10 for suicid-sheeps.

Early Access Review
								I don't like to do reviews for games, but Besiege is an exception; the sheer quality of this game for its stage of development is well worth the £5. The game is updated regularly, which supports the hypothesis that this game will reach full release which often dissuades people with early access games. It does have its bugs and occasionally clunky UI but it is a beautiful sandbox game with real potential. Besiege sparks the imagination to conjure weird, bizarre and wonderful creations that somehow manage to kill all of those suicidal sheep. Even if you do not consider yourself to be a 'creative' person, you will have fun for hours. If you put the time in, it can be hugely rewarding even in this limited state with only 15 levels and a sandbox mode.TL;DRGet the game, put the time in, have fun.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Once you get a few of the most useful mods, such as Precision Building Project 2, you'll realise this game could benefit greatly from reworked/updated building. For example, you can only rotate a block on one plane (clockwise and counter-clockwise), you can't just place blocks at half of the normal spacing, you actually have to make a sort of support to do that (in the vanilla version of the game, of course).The game's controls cannot be remapped which i find a little unfortunate. You'd want to build a machine that you control with the standard (for most people) WASD scheme only to find out that WASD is used to move the camera around (I barely use that feature at all).But, the game is otherwise really fun and has tons of potential.The artstyle is lovely, physics are fine as long as you arent fixed on building abominations that defy them, the background music fits the game well and it's just pretty addictive if I do say so myself.Also, don't let other people's creations discourage you. There's a lot of amazing besiege stuff out there, but people that make it probably started with making a simple wooden cart with four wheels that couldn't turn.9/10, worth the price

If you put the time in, it can be hugely rewarding even in this limited state with only 15 levels and a sandbox mode.TL;DRGet the game, put the time in, have fun.

Early Access Review
								Skeptical by the "Early Access" title, I thought this was going to be a game of broken promises. However, I decided to give it a shot just because I am a sucker for physics, building, and medieval genres. Besiege is on the path to be one of the best simulators on Steam. The goal is simple; complete the objective by any means you wish. The tools are quite versatile and allow you to go as far out as you want with your creations. Another dynamic aspect to the game is the physics engine. You could build the most awesome machine but every moment of force is calculated. Even just pulling too hard on your catapult and the whole thing might shatter into wooden bits. Watching shrapnel fly around and bodies ran from the sky will billows of smoke and fire is just purely satisfying.As of this review (2/10/2015), there is only one world available (a collection of levels) and a free building mode. There are quite a few worlds and modes that are listed as "coming soon". So hopefully we see further development of this title. 7$ is more than fair for what is available right now but I would pay even more money for a game full of levels, challenges, environments etc. Basically, the foundation as been laid out so well that as long as they continue to produce content, this game will be one of the top indie games of 2015.But as of now, considering how well polished the game is (I mean, just look at dem grafeeks), the intelligence of the physics engine, and the great tools, it's definitely worth a purchase.

Early Access Review
								Only a few hours into this game and already loving it. It's a great little building game where the objective is (usually) to smash enemy castles and armies to pieces with a siege machine of your own making. The game also mixes up the missions you do, so you may have to make a crane to collect resources and deliver it somewhere or torch a flock of seagulls. This adds a little spice to the flavour of the game.It reminds me a lot of Garry's mod - but with objectives. That is a huge plus in my book. Add multiplayer to this and it could well be one of the best games of all time. The price tag is also very welcoming for an EA title - too many devs these days are pricing their games over £15 for EA, which is a huge gamble for a game that is not finished. Besiege is also fairly bug free and plays very well. It looks and feels very polished for an Early Access game.All-in-all, this is definitely worthy of your time and I look forward to future developments. This is Early Access done right and I wish there was more like this on Steam.Jimbo Rating: 8/10

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								(Review date: 03/23/2015 - This is an Early Access game, the criticism on this Review may change as the game updates).Besiege is a Sandbox game which you have the power of building whatever you want, with objects such as Wheels, Weapons (Flame Throwers, Cannons, Water Cannons, Large Spikes and much more), and other objects which help with your vehicle/machine/thing to work (such as traction, suspensions and movements). You can pretty much build anything you like with the assets that the game comes with. You can also flip several objects to work in reverse ways (E.g.: Wheel running backwards), and so on. You can save your machines any time you like and how many you like as well.The game has a Sandbox mode and a Campaign mode. Right now only one "Chapter" of levels exist, you must build something in order to complete the mission/level (Reach some specific areas, destroy buildings, destroy a % of the people, and so on). The Campaign mode has a limited space for your building, so it's not that easy to pick up and win, but on the Sandbox, you can choose if you want a limited space (like the Campaign mode) or with no limitations.The game also supports the Steam Workshop which many people shares their own machines that may help you with the campaign or just to have fun on the Sandbox (some of them may extrapolate the space limit, so some of them only works on Sandbox mode).I give a recommendation, I had plans on buying this, but I got as a gift by one of my Friends. Gotta say it was a pretty good one. My only complaint are that the save progress doesn't go on Steam Cloud servers, if you're playing on multiple computers, you'll have different files for your Campaign save and your saved Machines.The price is very fair, but don't forget that this is on Early Access stage, so don't expect much of content right now.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Wonderful simulator where, by the looks of things, you play the role of a medieval psychopath who somehow managed to become a military engineer under a monarchic ruler that displays questionable decision-making skills. Your noble sponsor grants you access to all the resources you will need to build machines beyond imagination and sanity. No-one of the royal court will object your decision to siege a castle using a helicopter-catapult and neither they will question the viability of placing a flamethrower next to a wooden beam within your own construction – you are the military engineer and as long as enemies keep falling, you shall be rewarded generously. I say generously, but I simply mean that you will not be seeing your head on a pike of your own bewitched machine, which, frankly enough, used to be quite a big thing for anyone who practiced science in the medieval times.The game is relatively short at the moment, in fact it is extremely short, but there are promises to expand it significantly. Overall, it is still a nice and a simple game to enjoy in the evening at a price of your fancy Starbucks coffee drink. However, I do need to confess that I consume Starbucks coffee drinks on semi-regular basis, but no-one can judge me as for I am… THE (pronounce “e” as “i” in the word “this”) military engineer.

								It's the Kerbal Space Program but with siege weapons. Luckily since this game is still early access we can at least hope for greater mission variety in some future updates. But as of right now, I'm going to say 4/10. Sound/Music quality is inconsequential at this point as there is no music and what sound effects are in the game are more atmospheric than anything else. Sure, cannons make a shooting noise or bombs blow up, but there really is no reason to try and check this aspect at this early a stage of this game's development. X/10.

Posted: February 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's one of those "has a lot of potential" games.The graphics are very nice and the physics more or less work fine. Building siege weapons is easy enough even for someone not bless with engineering skills. Though if you think that you can build something that turns and moves quickly and gently - think again. Its more or less "cow on a roller-blades" situation with everything you are going to build.Flying... doesn't really work. I've tried different ways to build flying mechanisms and all of them cannot be controlled for more than 3 seconds before falling down and breaking into pieces.At the moment there's nothing really to do here. First island can be finished in under 30 minutes, a lot of the sounds are missing, there barely any music, very few parts and enemies as well. The sandbox is fun for exactly 10 minutes before you realize that you pretty much tried everything you could to build something amazing and failed miserably.So... yeah - it has potential but right now its barren. Though i suppose that the small price is its redeeming quality. You can buy it if you are prepared to wait for whatever amount of time it takes the developers to finish it.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Besiege is a physics based game where only your creativity and maybe a little bit of your luck can help you.Besiege may look like a game you will play for a day or two and then you will forget about it forever. But if you ask me i can see lots of potential in the game .why you will as ? well let me explaine-Because it does something not many games even dare to do in our days , is make a game where you need to think and use your Imagination.Sadly in our days most of the games are based on simple rules or maybe not even a single rule , leaving you just looking at the screen and clicking.  And besiege is not one of those games. Besiege has no real tutorial as you get into the game. So its your duty to figure out how to play. But don't worry its not just trows you into the water and says swim ****! No its starts slowly with an easy task and slowly moves to bigger and harder challenges.Right now as its in alpha its not much contant, yes . but as i said its only alpha so meaning lots of contant will be added in the near future. And already you can see whats the map size is going to be and what the devs are working on and (hell know how many levels every piece of land contains).Plus for the price tag of 6.99$ you can't really complain , and the replay ability is huge.And if you're still scared picking this game up just because its in "alpha" and its "100% full of bugs and all those things" forget about it. As long as i have played there are no bugs at all, yes im pretty sure its not gonna be some bugs here and there. But even if you find some they are so little and unnoticeable at first you would not even care. So if you ask me the game is in alpha just because its really not that much contant, but even now its lots of what you can do.So if you ever had an idea of picking up Besiege go for it 100% i think its a wonderful game and its for sure deserves your attention.Thank you for reading my review and peace ! <3

								Blam!!, i watch in dismay as another one of my designs crubles before me, another innovative idea gone. Early Access Review
								If you're into building machines capable of blowing up an entire castle, then look no further, this is the game for you. It has strong aspects when it comes to physics, which behaved 'rather' realistically. The game so far is worth it for its price, despite it being an early access game. I have to say this is probably one the best...no, no, THE BEST early access game I've ever played, for its price I would get it right now!~Do remember, THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW!!!Pros:-Realistic Physics-Easy building mechanic (nothing fancy)-Medival LegosCons:-Messy Camera angles (please do fix this, its a very annoying downside to the game)-Not yet optimised properly (this occurs when you build a medium-large machine and your FPS drops from 55 to 12 when you try and simulate it).-Lacks flight options (A lot, in fact)Overall, this game has a lot of potential especially when those 'cons' are taken care of. FOR THE DEVS, I would like to see more awesome content in the future and more 'flight' options.I would give this game an early access score of 85/100

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a physics puzzler by which you need to build different siege engines to accomplish each level's objective. For instance, the first level requires you to destroy a small house. The second level requires you to adapt your design to destroy a windmill on a hill. The current levels as of February 8th are 15 campaign levels and a sanbbox obstacle course. The parts to build with are varied from basic blocks to pistons to springs and many other weapons like blades, spikes, and even bombd. And the build mode is very intuitive. The graphics settings can enable and disable SSAO, Shadows, Bloom, and Vignette. In the same settings folder, you can find an option to ignite anything with a click of a button, and disable the build limits.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's a lot of great things to say about this game.  The graphics and models are easy on the eyes, the music is serene, and the physics are pretty darned realistic.  My only complaint is the lack of a tutorial, which is significant considering the learning curve.  I admit that I did partially have fun failing in the creations I made, but I also found myself frustrated at times because I couldn't figure out how certain parts worked together.  I'm hoping to see some sort of in-game video tutorial showing first-time players how most of these parts function as a whole.  For now, I'll be consulting Wikis and YouTube videos.  Considering the price however, I'd say that $6.99 is a great deal for what you're getting here.

I have to say this is probably one the best...no, no, THE BEST early access game I've ever played, for its price I would get it right now!~Do remember, THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW!!!Pros:-Realistic Physics-Easy building mechanic (nothing fancy)-Medival LegosCons:-Messy Camera angles (please do fix this, its a very annoying downside to the game)-Not yet optimised properly (this occurs when you build a medium-large machine and your FPS drops from 55 to 12 when you try and simulate it).-Lacks flight options (A lot, in fact)Overall, this game has a lot of potential especially when those 'cons' are taken care of. FOR THE DEVS, I would like to see more awesome content in the future and more 'flight' options.I would give this game an early access score of 85/100
