Early Access Review
Funny, Creative, and very easy to get into.Besiege is a game where you build contraptions to complete the objective(s) in each stage. Every stage can be completed in a multitude of different ways, as long as you complete the required objective(s). This game is open from start to finish, you dont have to beat every stage to unlock certain parts, cheats, or any feature, You can even disable the box which limits how big your creation can be, and where it spawns (this ofcourse prevents level progression, but all the levels are already unlocked for you). There are quite a few parts, ranging from construction bits, to mechanical moving parts, and weapons. You can build anything from a medieval tank, a catapult, and even a giant walking death robot with the right skill and parts.You dont need a NASA gaming computer to run this game (however it does help if you build absurdly large creations with tons of moving parts), and for only $6.99 this game is excellent. There are few to no game breaking bugs that I can think of or have encountered, and the game runs very smooth. If you dont know what to buy, and have 7 dollars, pick this game up, its great.

content:

Early Access Review
								(1/31/2015) Excellent game! Despite not having very many levels at this point in early access, the existing ones are diverse and fun to replay. The physics are simulated well and the game looks very nice, with a kind of "vignette" effect. The tutorial is sparse, but the UI is simple and easy to understand (and looks GREAT!) so you can tinker around freely and get a feel for how each part works within an hour or so of gameplay. Since it's a very open-ended game you really have to think about how to complete the objectives, so you'll pass through the levels only as fast as you can engineer working machines. I found that the pacing worked out well for me but I can imagine steam workshop integration being a godsend for less patient folks. Overall very solid and fun game, I recommend it especially at the current price!

content:

Early Access Review
								Great game, nuff said, but I'll say more.The first thing you'll notice is the polish.  Simply launching the game only takes half a second to load, which is pretty amazing.  You'll then find yourself with a UI so beautiful it will bring tears to the eyes.Gameplay is simple, but fun with lots of room open to experiment in trying to build more advanced things.Before I get into the bad, just buy it, it's great.  The only reason my negative list is longer is so many things are good I can't even think of them all.You'll see a lot of people complain about the camera.  After looking into it though, I realized it's not because the controls are bad, they make a lot of sense really, the problem is arrow keys are movement and WASD + mouse is camera.  If you're left handed you'll be fine, right handed though? RIP.The physics are fun, but the gameplay speed highly effects how they work.  At 100% catapults will almost always blow themselves up.  I found it nessacary to bring it to 15% a lot to not blow up.  Also, %50 feels like what normal simulation speed should be.The game is pretty short.  I LP'd it start to finish, with some basic understanding of the game going in, in 2 hours.  Then did about 30 minutes of messing around in sandbox and felt done.  There's more coming I know, but yeah, it's quick if you don't like messing around.Side Note:  If a dev reads this, I think you should try really hard to get steam workshop integration going.  If you give players the tools to make challenges it will extend the life time of the game a billion-fold.

Early Access Review
Funny, Creative, and very easy to get into.Besiege is a game where you build contraptions to complete the objective(s) in each stage. Every stage can be completed in a multitude of different ways, as long as you complete the required objective(s). This game is open from start to finish, you dont have to beat every stage to unlock certain parts, cheats, or any feature, You can even disable the box which limits how big your creation can be, and where it spawns (this ofcourse prevents level progression, but all the levels are already unlocked for you). There are quite a few parts, ranging from construction bits, to mechanical moving parts, and weapons. You can build anything from a medieval tank, a catapult, and even a giant walking death robot with the right skill and parts.You dont need a NASA gaming computer to run this game (however it does help if you build absurdly large creations with tons of moving parts), and for only $6.99 this game is excellent. There are few to no game breaking bugs that I can think of or have encountered, and the game runs very smooth. If you dont know what to buy, and have 7 dollars, pick this game up, its great.

Early Access Review
								A game that is in early devolpment, and isn't about plane crashes, voxel survival, or a zombie plague? Gaben be praised!Well worth the 7 dollars, not much in the game yet but the possiblites look great. Workshop add-ons, multiplayer contraption figthing, and a fun sandbox buliding game similar to kerbal space program is what I hope see in this game's future. Also it runs very well for a unfinshed game (unless you place way more blocks and parts than you know you should be). Solid frame rate and great graphics. Looks very polished even though it's still in development. The only bug I ran into was that sometimes you accidently might put 2 parts in one spot if your clicking too fast and not paying attention. That might be my mouse however. I suggest you pick it up if you have an extra 7 dollars laying around or the game goes on sale. It's pretty fun, and more updates are bound to come. For now, it just has a few fun levels and a sandbox. So don't excpect that much to do until some extra content get's rolled out. But still a pretty solid game. 7/10 for what it has to offer as of now.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I was a small child, I would always draw designs for cars and stuff. Bikes sometimes. Vehicles that moved, and I would come up with all these little mechanisms for them that surely wouldn't work.And now Besiege has come along and I'm doing it all over again.The thing that makes this such a great Early Access game is the content and the price. It's currently in active development, not even close to complete, and the content that I have right now is fully worth the $7 price tag to me. The experimentation is simply so joyous. In the few hours I've played so far, I never take the time to fully think my ideas through. I throw them out there, see what works, see what doesn't, and keep adapting them until I have exactly what I want. It's great fun to play with friends around too, as group idea sessions are the best kind of idea sessions.Any negatives? Obviously early access and unfinished, but again, worthy content already, My only qualm is the guilt I feel when I accidentally murder an innocent sheep, but I'm quickly becoming numb. Definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								TIP: When building your structures it does not matter if it survives till the next round. As long as it accomplishes the goal, anything goes!I enjoy that there isn't any rigid building limits in the game even on the first stage. There is a size limit, but it can be removed and is pretty large anyway. If you want to build a 20 cannon war machine just to destroy a small farmhouse and 4 sheep in the first stage you can. I've played this more hours than steam has tracked because I got this via the humble bundle instead, which gives you the DRM free version of this game, a steam key as well as a linux/mac version.Anyway for the price its many hours of fun. No tutorials really so you will want to take the time to fiddle with the parts to see how they can be used. Or watch a youtube video of some of the other players if you want to lean on their experience.

								After watching some videos of Jacksepticguy play Beseige, I thought to myself, "Why wouldn't I want to play it?" content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								So, what's good about this game?+An incredible amount of things to create, ranging from tanks, giant robots, helicopters, or fortresses.+Getting started is pretty simple since the build system is pretty intuitive.+There's a good diversity of mechanical systems which make the first point possible.+The UI is pretty user-friendly.+It appeals to that little destructive tendency that many of us seem to have.Problems:-Well, it's still early access, so things will seem a bit limited sometimes.-Building particularly large contraptions sometimes seems a bit time-consuming as there appears to be no way to place blocks en masse just yet (unless I'm missing something). Making large panels can take quite a while.-Sometimes building feels a bit constrained due to the grid-based nature of the build system, and the fact that the vast majority of blocks are cubic (there are some ways to mess around with the dimensions and break out of the grid, but it's going to make things very difficult and has limited applications).The game is certainly well-made, but the early-access situation makes itself evident with a lack of a few features that could facilitate building some larger machines. Regardless of the issues, the fun of the game is certainly enough to make up for the minor gripes, and the fact that it is early-access at the time of this writing very well means that the minor gripes can be fixed as time goes on.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								My friends and I refer to this game as Kerbal Siege Program.Essentially, build a mighty machine, test it and watch it explode. Make adjustments and watch machine explode in more and more entertaining ways, until it eventually blows up so spectacularly it ends up completing the level.There are (at the time of writing) only 15 levels (and a sandbox arena) but even then the game encompasses raiding, pillaging, short-range destruction, long-ranged destruction, scattering massed ranks of troops, stealing the enemy's stuff, navigating minefields and traversing a mountain pass while under fire.Oh, and butchering a herd of sheep. That's a thing.On a more serious note, this game is really quite exceptional. It's easy to get started, but your machines can be as complex or as simple as you like. Also the art style is really neat, and although the physics can get a little bit mediaeval at times (*cough* perpetual motion machines *cough*) the game is surprisingly well-polished for an alpha, and I can only see the game improving as more content is added, both in the form of levels and parts. Sharing machines is also possible, although that's the only multiplayer experience the game currently offers. Nonetheless, I can't help but give this game 10/10, it's without a doubt the most promising game I've ever played.

They will probably add more, but even like this, it is a good compromise between having a compact set of blocks (so that they are easy to remember and find) and a lot of building options. Also, since you can define which keys control each block, you can even do things like differential tank-like steering, where you control wheels on each side separately, allowing you to turn on the spot.

content:

Early Access Review
								Besiege, a game with one problem and multiple ways to solve that problem. Sounds like a lot of games, right? WRONG! Your views completely shift when the problem becomes "why is this building still standing?" and the solution: BESIEGE. Take control of the builder mode where you are given a box and can build whatever you want in that box. Want a snake-thing that can shoot flames? Thats nice. Or maybe a droid with cannons? Thats cool too. But if you don't like thinking inside the box, thats fine, just delete the box! Now, which do you wanna build? The giant four-legged monster that can level an entire town with one foot? Or the catapult that fires giant flaming boulders across the map? Or... something of your own imagination? The choices are endless, and this is just the beginning! How can there be a start to something that goes on forever? Easy, start with the Starting block and go from there. This isn't even the full game yet! The developers really have something here, and I aplaud their work. And the physics are amazing! Watch out for the flamethrowers because your wooden machine could become a smoldering pile of coal and metal bits. Oh, theres a building in your way? Tak it down with a well placed cannon shot... or a fist punch... or a bomb drop... or a plane crash... or a flying boulder... or a flying sheep... over a speeding car... or a wirring fan blade... or a spike piston... or a gyro ball... or a tank... or a giraffe... The choices are endless! So what are you waiting for? The tooth fairy to come and give you money? Christmas? Your Birthday? Well I'm here to say: "Happy Birthday, happy quanza, happy new year, happy christmas, happy easter, happy jubalee for christs sake! Do yourself a favor and get BESIEGE! One problem besiege doesn't have is not being able to press the "like" button enough!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								(For pro's and cons, skip to the botttom)This is probably the most fun few hours i've ever had on any game.At first, you might look at Besiege and think that, because of the apparent lack of content, it's just another incomplete steam early access game, and therefore not worth the money at this stage. This COULDNT be further from the truth.From what I've played so far, the levels are all based on simple concepts (move this, destroy that, get to their etc) but it's surprising how replayable the levels are. This is simply down to the fact that you can complete the levels in any way you see fit, building whatever mad contraptions come into your head. The building mechanics in this game are superb, and it's strangely satisfying to see your creation coming together. On top of that, this game is GORGEOUS. The fire and blood effects look fantastic, and the quirky art style really adds uniqueness to the game.I do have some minor quibbles, however. Sometimes (and this might just be down to my lack of skill, but it is nonetheless a fault), I find that the camera is a little awkward to control, particulary when you are trying place small components in specific places. On top of that, players of other physics sandbox games may be slightly frustrated at the limited types of parts. However, seeing as this game is still an alpha, I'm willing to forgive it for this, especially as the developers seem to be very active (there are reportedly several other game modes and mechanics already in development).Overall, besiege is a fantastic little game, and shows real polish, even in its current state. Best of all?£5/$7.Pros:Addictive and replayable levelsExcellent building mechanicsFantastic art style/graphicsActive, supportive developers and communityBeautifilly polished and (so far in my playtime) bug freePromises of many future updatesCheap!Cons:Slightly awkward camera movementLimited amount of components

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Normally I would never tell people to buy into early access. However, I will just say this: This game in alpha with 2 more years of development to go is more fun, more polished, and more feature complete for 7$ than a lot of buggy piece of crap AAA titles out there that are charging you 60$.Whats awesome about it:Unlike a lot of sandbox games that have level progressions and slowly dole out the blocks to try to make you complete the levels, this game just gives you all the stuff and says "Hey, here you go! Go to town!" And it's glorious.There are no artificial restrictions placed on you either. There is no "You can only place 4 cannons in this level!" kind of thing. The only restriction is a simple bounding box. As long as your machine fits in the bounding box the game doesn't care what you do. Want to make a giant wall with 200 cannons and 50 flame throwers? Go for it! Want to make a flying machine carrying 10 bombs and fly it straight into a castle? Go for it! There are a zillion ways to solve the levels, and no right answer.And you would think that would make the game too easy, but trust me it doesn't. The physics and engineering principles are what make the games difficulty.The only thing I would complain about if I was going to complain is the lack of content, And by content I mean there is only like 15 levels atm. But I can't really complain about that because it's in alpha early access so there you go. The amount of things you can do with the limited content already is amazing.So to make a long story short (too late), this game does one thing and does it very well. If you like to build things, then watch as it and everything else on the screen blows up in a massive mushroom cloud of hilarious blood, fire, and death you should buy this game. This is early access done right. You won't be dissapointed.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Lovely visuals, a solid physics simulation, a good set of blocks/devices to use, and some well designed puzzles that can truly be solved in a variety of ways. Having to think about the physics of the device you're building, and discovering new ways to combine things for the desired effect, make this a joy to play for anyone who likes solving physics puzzles.The tutorial does NOT teach you how to use all the components, nor should it IMO. It gives you a basic introduction to just a couple of them, and then leaves you to discover the rest yourself. Personally, I love the feeling of discovery that comes with learning how to use a component for the first time, and having the possibilities the component unlocks unfold in my mind.To be clear, it could use some quality of life improvements to help with construction of your devices/vehicles, like:- ability to select and move groups of blocks, or to copy/paste block sets- ability to copy/paste the properties of components without so much clicking (needs a hotkey paste)I'd also say they should change the default controls so that wasd will control device movement instead of the camera, and put the camera controls on the arrow keys, but it's managable.More levels will also be very welcome, as I "finished" all the available levels (30ish) in something like 6 hours, but they're working on that.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								So, what's good about this game?+An incredible amount of things to create, ranging from tanks, giant robots, helicopters, or fortresses.+Getting started is pretty simple since the build system is pretty intuitive.+There's a good diversity of mechanical systems which make the first point possible.+The UI is pretty user-friendly.+It appeals to that little destructive tendency that many of us seem to have.Problems:-Well, it's still early access, so things will seem a bit limited sometimes.-Building particularly large contraptions sometimes seems a bit time-consuming as there appears to be no way to place blocks en masse just yet (unless I'm missing something). Making large panels can take quite a while.-Sometimes building feels a bit constrained due to the grid-based nature of the build system, and the fact that the vast majority of blocks are cubic (there are some ways to mess around with the dimensions and break out of the grid, but it's going to make things very difficult and has limited applications).The game is certainly well-made, but the early-access situation makes itself evident with a lack of a few features that could facilitate building some larger machines. Regardless of the issues, the fun of the game is certainly enough to make up for the minor gripes, and the fact that it is early-access at the time of this writing very well means that the minor gripes can be fixed as time goes on.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Normally I would never tell people to buy into early access. However, I will just say this: This game in alpha with 2 more years of development to go is more fun, more polished, and more feature complete for 7$ than a lot of buggy piece of crap AAA titles out there that are charging you 60$.Whats awesome about it:Unlike a lot of sandbox games that have level progressions and slowly dole out the blocks to try to make you complete the levels, this game just gives you all the stuff and says "Hey, here you go! Go to town!" And it's glorious.There are no artificial restrictions placed on you either. There is no "You can only place 4 cannons in this level!" kind of thing. The only restriction is a simple bounding box. As long as your machine fits in the bounding box the game doesn't care what you do. Want to make a giant wall with 200 cannons and 50 flame throwers? Go for it! Want to make a flying machine carrying 10 bombs and fly it straight into a castle? Go for it! There are a zillion ways to solve the levels, and no right answer.And you would think that would make the game too easy, but trust me it doesn't. The physics and engineering principles are what make the games difficulty.The only thing I would complain about if I was going to complain is the lack of content, And by content I mean there is only like 15 levels atm. But I can't really complain about that because it's in alpha early access so there you go. The amount of things you can do with the limited content already is amazing.So to make a long story short (too late), this game does one thing and does it very well. If you like to build things, then watch as it and everything else on the screen blows up in a massive mushroom cloud of hilarious blood, fire, and death you should buy this game. This is early access done right. You won't be dissapointed.

Early Access Review
								If you like building stuff and making crash and/or blow things up, then get this game!Think of lego with a physics engine, damage system and explosions. lots of fire and explosions.Once you start this game, you are thrown into a world, where your only objective is to kill, burn or destroy everything in your path, with whatever insane war machine you create. Many parts exist to create what ever you want, including propellors, pistons, hinges, joints, or something more fun like cannons and flamethrowers. The only issue I have with this game is that this game experiences a lot of slowdown with the more parts you add. Since each part undergoes its own physics, larger crafts tend to break apart more easily, and buckling causes a lot of lag on slower machines ( like mine D: )but if you are able to work around this, you can create almost anything, including planes, catapults, helicopters or even mecha walkers, if you have the knowhow. Since parts must have their keys bound separatley to different keys, it opens up alot of possibility but also increases the difficulty of creating things. If this isnt your kind of consturction style, try out robocraft, its free and much easier to build in. Either way, I strongy reccomend both.  happy slaughtering! :)

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								While the point of this game is simple (make a machine that completes the given objective), the machine that you build can be as complex as your imagination allows. Each level offers an objective, such as kill the soldiers or destroy 80% of this castle. You're allowed to build a machine that completes the objective within a certain sized cube (I think each side is about 20 blocks). If you want to build bigger, there is sandbox mode that removes the size restriction, but it prevents unlocking the next level. At this stage in development the game offers about 20 unique pieces to build with, but I've never wished for any additional pieces. There's so many different ways to combine pieces to make a workable machine. Additionally, certain pieces allow customization, such as changing the rotation speed of a spinning block or how much a spring resists motion. The only limitation to this game is your imagination; Besiege is a blast as long as you can think of something to build.The only downside I've encountered is that it's often the simplest machines that complete the objective. I was able to pass the sheep level by using a basic car and running the sheep over. I would really enjoy additional levels that wouldn't let me be so lazy. I say this because the game shines when you try to build crazy machines that test the laws of physics. The most fun I've had is watching my machines, particularly those built with bombs or contractable springs, catastrophically fail. However, there is no greater sense of accomplishment when you build a crafty machine that is able to pass a level.At $7, this is the best early access purchase I've ever made. For the price it already feels complete and the developer plans to add more levels at different locations (like the moon!) and more pieces to build. I should note that the game has already been updated with a few new pieces (cogs, boulder, low-friction half-pipe).Things I like:  Graphics: They aren't really high definition, but the style is enchanting. I can't find words to describe it.  Reseting the camera: The camera is fairly wonky, but it's easily reset.  Saving machines: Starting from scratch every time would suck.Things I dislike:  Collision physics: Some moving parts phase through others without breaking, usually when parts are moving fast. Not sure what that's about. It's hilarious though.  My deficient imagination: I would play more often if I could think of things to build.Unless you have no creativity and no imagination, buy this game! If you need more convincing just look up hilarious videos online of various machines people have already built.

Early Access Review
								Besiege is one of those rare experimental games that asks the right question and gives you the right answer.Question: How would it feel like to be able to build your own siege weapons and then get to use them to overcome obstacles like castles, windmills and sheeps?Answer: Besiege.The game is in production at the time of this writing, but already it is both functional and gorgeous.The building tools are intuitive so that you will be building out of your imagination in no time and the attention to details is superb. The world of Besiege looks warm, unique and welcoming.Building siege weapons to destroy things is a simple premise, so Besiege gives you a level progression system with objectives.Each level has specific objectives, so you have to think creatively and design wisely in order to achieve the objectives.My only critique is that it would have been nice to have had a simple story campaign attached to the formula, but given that this is an indie game, I can understand why they would want to focus on the core design for the first game.Get Besiege if you like the idea of building your own siege weapons and testing their efficiency.Avoid if experimental building games are not your cup of tea.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Imagine yourself how you construct a medieval machine that can kill innocent people and sheep’s or destroy buildings like windmills and forts. Welcome to Besiege, the physics based building game that allows you to build this and very much more. If you want to know what you can create, take a look at the workshop and enjoy all the creations constructed by players, it’s impressive what you can do. All you need is creativity, patience and a bit knowledge about physic.GameplayTo learn the basics you can play the little campaign which includes a few levels with a task that you have to complete. Most of the time you should kill soldiers, sheep’s or destroy the buildings. At the beginning it’s easy but at the end it’s a challenge. There is also a sandbox mode where you can create your constructions without limits and all the time you need. You want to create a real tank? Do it! You want to build a mass murder machine? What are you waiting for? I could list a lot more things but to keep it short: Build what you want! If you need inspiration you can go to the workshop or look a few videos, there are also many tutorials out there that helps you to understand the game. GraphicBesiege has a minimalistic art style and it looks awesome. It’s a unique graphic style that I’ve never seen before. The hand drawn textures are very clear and very detailed. Also the User Interface, that’s clear to and practically. But don’t underestimate this game when it comes to the performance. This game is like a physics simulator and need a strong PC to run smooth. Bigger constructions with many movable parts need a powerful system. ParticularitiesAs I said above, that game has realistic physic effects. That means that you have to consider the gravity. If you build a large object with wood, you have to stabilize it with some metal or it will break up. The physics are the real challenge in this game. Besiege is a nice game if you are creative, have patience and understand the physics of the world. If you like constructing machines in a sandbox world than you should get it instantly, it’s totally worth it. I have a lot of fun with this game, to build some crazy machines or improve objects form the workshop. Should be in every library.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								​It's like somebody saw how my friends and I played with legos as kids and turned it into a game.  While the early access version (as of v 0.4) is light on scenarios/puzzles, the siege-engine building is fully functional and remarkably fun.  It is easy to construct a basic working siege engine in a few minutes though more time and experimentation is rewarded as the simulation and construction tools allow you to create everything from basic catapults to walking/flying/transforming death machines.The only thing that could be said to be missing at this point is a suite of puzzles/challenges commensurate to the tools you are given.  The current puzzle set serves as a good basic tutorial but does not offer much challenge on its own.   Once beaten, the available levels and the sandbox mode mostly serve as testing grounds in which to play around with building even more insane creations.  There are many more levels in development, but if sandbox construction doesn't sound like your thing it might make sense to hold off until the rest of the levels are completed.Even at this early stage it is worth the price of admission; if you do not tend to buy early access titles then keep an eye on this one as it is sure to be even more impressive at launch.    While the devs are still adding more features at this point and have yet to add most of the pre-built challenge levels, there's still enough here to provide several hours of great entertainment already - if you enjoy making giant dancing robots who tear themselves to pieces as they crush medieval villages under foot.​

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								​It's like somebody saw how my friends and I played with legos as kids and turned it into a game.  While the early access version (as of v 0.4) is light on scenarios/puzzles, the siege-engine building is fully functional and remarkably fun.  It is easy to construct a basic working siege engine in a few minutes though more time and experimentation is rewarded as the simulation and construction tools allow you to create everything from basic catapults to walking/flying/transforming death machines.The only thing that could be said to be missing at this point is a suite of puzzles/challenges commensurate to the tools you are given.  The current puzzle set serves as a good basic tutorial but does not offer much challenge on its own.   Once beaten, the available levels and the sandbox mode mostly serve as testing grounds in which to play around with building even more insane creations.  There are many more levels in development, but if sandbox construction doesn't sound like your thing it might make sense to hold off until the rest of the levels are completed.Even at this early stage it is worth the price of admission; if you do not tend to buy early access titles then keep an eye on this one as it is sure to be even more impressive at launch.    While the devs are still adding more features at this point and have yet to add most of the pre-built challenge levels, there's still enough here to provide several hours of great entertainment already - if you enjoy making giant dancing robots who tear themselves to pieces as they crush medieval villages under foot.​

content:

Early Access Review
								Steam Review -  Beat a castle by building a pyramid of explosvies and ramming it through soldiers to hit the walls. 10/10Serious review:This game is excellent, and even at it's current level, I would be quite happy to pay £2-3 for it. However, the game menu (a beautiful spinning globe) shows several levels, portrayed as continents, that are purportedly 'under construction' along with a sandbox mode. When (hopefully) these come out, the game will quite probably take many hours to complete. My current playtime of 3.2 hours was enough to complete the current levels, while mucking about with various ways to kill sheep, and so is probably 2 hours play for someone new, with no ideas borrowed from videos. For only £4.99, and the hope of another 3-5 campaigns of the same length, this gives better £ to hour ratio than I expected, and certainly beats some of the more expensive games availble.I highly recommend this, however, before you build a metal plated explosive firing tank, be aware, I did this, and my FPS promtly dropped to 5. Whether this is unavoidable or not I don't know, it may have been the object I made, but I hope the developers add either better optimisation for more 'parts' of vehicles, or add larger blocks, such as a 5x2 metal plate, so you can armour things without playing a slideshow.However, other than that small qualm, this game is absolutely excellent, and will easily provide hours of entertaining play.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								My friends and I refer to this game as Kerbal Siege Program.Essentially, build a mighty machine, test it and watch it explode. Make adjustments and watch machine explode in more and more entertaining ways, until it eventually blows up so spectacularly it ends up completing the level.There are (at the time of writing) only 15 levels (and a sandbox arena) but even then the game encompasses raiding, pillaging, short-range destruction, long-ranged destruction, scattering massed ranks of troops, stealing the enemy's stuff, navigating minefields and traversing a mountain pass while under fire.Oh, and butchering a herd of sheep. That's a thing.On a more serious note, this game is really quite exceptional. It's easy to get started, but your machines can be as complex or as simple as you like. Also the art style is really neat, and although the physics can get a little bit mediaeval at times (*cough* perpetual motion machines *cough*) the game is surprisingly well-polished for an alpha, and I can only see the game improving as more content is added, both in the form of levels and parts. Sharing machines is also possible, although that's the only multiplayer experience the game currently offers. Nonetheless, I can't help but give this game 10/10, it's without a doubt the most promising game I've ever played.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Lovely visuals, a solid physics simulation, a good set of blocks/devices to use, and some well designed puzzles that can truly be solved in a variety of ways. Having to think about the physics of the device you're building, and discovering new ways to combine things for the desired effect, make this a joy to play for anyone who likes solving physics puzzles.The tutorial does NOT teach you how to use all the components, nor should it IMO. It gives you a basic introduction to just a couple of them, and then leaves you to discover the rest yourself. Personally, I love the feeling of discovery that comes with learning how to use a component for the first time, and having the possibilities the component unlocks unfold in my mind.To be clear, it could use some quality of life improvements to help with construction of your devices/vehicles, like:- ability to select and move groups of blocks, or to copy/paste block sets- ability to copy/paste the properties of components without so much clicking (needs a hotkey paste)I'd also say they should change the default controls so that wasd will control device movement instead of the camera, and put the camera controls on the arrow keys, but it's managable.More levels will also be very welcome, as I "finished" all the available levels (30ish) in something like 6 hours, but they're working on that.

content:

Early Access Review
								I have not played this game long; but in the time I have it has been more than just enjoyable. At first I bought it with the faint idea that I'd only be destroying things with my contraptions. I call them "contraptions" because I named them ridiculous things. That it would be walls, castles, and perhaps villages in that I was not wrong but there was more to this game. With imagination comes creativity and with those 2 together there is a bloom of comedy. Ideas of getting villagers/settlers (Please correct me on what they're called) on my contraptions was fairly amusing. Whether it was on a land-craft or aeronautic vehicle didn't matter I always had a pilot.I would highly recommend this game to anyone who has time for it. While you can have simple builds, one thing will lead to another and you're building a whole infrastructure for a wooden space launch. I loved that I could save my builds, that an icon was generated for them, and that I could download other builds. The game is truly a masterpiece in the making. There are mods out there which give the game more flexibility than it already has. I do hope and wish that in time the default game will implement them indefinitely. I am eager to see what is to come.

content:
Posted: January 24
Early Access Review
								I can warmly recommend this game to anyone who likes destruction or building gamesThe trailers just show simple destruction and explosions, but there is so much more to it!With bsg. editing or buiding mods, you can enhance besiege immeasurebly:You can now build  smooth sleek creations, creating jets or monster trucks with incredible detailedness,you can change parameters to the point where reality itself starts to crumble,discovering bugs yet unknown to man, creating surreal machines.But you can also challenge yourself and build equally amazing vanilla creations wich can keep up with modded machines with ease and excelence, beating multiple Isles with one single creation consisting of just ten blocks or less.Or you can just download creations, enjoying the intricate and creatively destructive masterpieces.Just don't expect to have significant long-time challenges delivered by the game itself,you have to be able to enjoy a game without a story or many instructions to like besiege.But this is the true beauty of besiege: you can build whaterver you would like to build.You also have to keep in mind that you can't just start the game and build the most awesome creations in the entire workshop, it takes quite some time until you are a fully experienced Besiegeneer. Starting to buildA few tipsBesiege is a suprisingly complex game even though it just seems like a small buiding game you can play for a bit. That's why anyone who really wants to start building should read as much guides as you can find and seek the advice of more experienced members of the community, but probably the most important thing of all: Practice. I would describe myself as a besiege-scientist who loves to discover (hopefully) amazing bugs, and I personally use a „trick“ to build my creations: I think of besiege as a kind of alternate reality.(And yes, that might sound kind of crazy but wait!)Just like our world, it too is gowerned by strict laws wich generate a beautifull complexity, just like in the real world, you can take a close look at those laws and understand them,eventually thinking just like a inhabitant inside of the game would. And at that point, not even the sky is your limit. You can just glitch it out of your way. But hey, thats just my crazy way of playing and understanding besiege.Recommended ModsBuilding Tool mod by The Guys You DespisePrecision Building Project 2 by ITRNo Bounds Mod by ITRYou can find a site with all mods here![forum.spiderlinggames.co.uk]Recommended GuidesBesiege for BeginnersThe most basic basics.Neutex's Guide on Advanced EngineeringA guide of excelent quality, highly recommended.Advanced GlitchingRequires mods or bsg. file editingThe two guides are made by me, and yes, there is probably a bit of bias involved...-bsg.-file editing made easy- A must-watch for basically everyone, it describes bsg.-file editing in depth while being easy to understand, enabling you to edit the save files like a pro.Also, quick personal tip: You can reverse engineer any feature of a machine by saving it and searching in the save file for the controll key of the feature.Or look for hidden blocks by searching: <Scale x="0" y="0" z="1" /> and its variations.The Great Guide on Particle GeneratorsA big with guide on a glitch-weapon class, written with scientific depth and detailednessLevitation through Vector EntanglementThis guide introduces a revolutionary building mechanic that makes building stable aircraft ridiculously easy.And if you made it all the way down here, Just buy the damn game, it costs hardly anything at all and is absolutely amazing.

								My first creation in this game was a small vehicle covered in cannons and flamethrowers. content:
Posted: January 24
Early Access Review
								I can warmly recommend this game to anyone who likes destruction or building gamesThe trailers just show simple destruction and explosions, but there is so much more to it!With bsg. editing or buiding mods, you can enhance besiege immeasurebly:You can now build  smooth sleek creations, creating jets or monster trucks with incredible detailedness,you can change parameters to the point where reality itself starts to crumble,discovering bugs yet unknown to man, creating surreal machines.But you can also challenge yourself and build equally amazing vanilla creations wich can keep up with modded machines with ease and excelence, beating multiple Isles with one single creation consisting of just ten blocks or less.Or you can just download creations, enjoying the intricate and creatively destructive masterpieces.Just don't expect to have significant long-time challenges delivered by the game itself,you have to be able to enjoy a game without a story or many instructions to like besiege.But this is the true beauty of besiege: you can build whaterver you would like to build.You also have to keep in mind that you can't just start the game and build the most awesome creations in the entire workshop, it takes quite some time until you are a fully experienced Besiegeneer. Starting to buildA few tipsBesiege is a suprisingly complex game even though it just seems like a small buiding game you can play for a bit. That's why anyone who really wants to start building should read as much guides as you can find and seek the advice of more experienced members of the community, but probably the most important thing of all: Practice. I would describe myself as a besiege-scientist who loves to discover (hopefully) amazing bugs, and I personally use a „trick“ to build my creations: I think of besiege as a kind of alternate reality.(And yes, that might sound kind of crazy but wait!)Just like our world, it too is gowerned by strict laws wich generate a beautifull complexity, just like in the real world, you can take a close look at those laws and understand them,eventually thinking just like a inhabitant inside of the game would. And at that point, not even the sky is your limit. You can just glitch it out of your way. But hey, thats just my crazy way of playing and understanding besiege.Recommended ModsBuilding Tool mod by The Guys You DespisePrecision Building Project 2 by ITRNo Bounds Mod by ITRYou can find a site with all mods here![forum.spiderlinggames.co.uk]Recommended GuidesBesiege for BeginnersThe most basic basics.Neutex's Guide on Advanced EngineeringA guide of excelent quality, highly recommended.Advanced GlitchingRequires mods or bsg. file editingThe two guides are made by me, and yes, there is probably a bit of bias involved...-bsg.-file editing made easy- A must-watch for basically everyone, it describes bsg.-file editing in depth while being easy to understand, enabling you to edit the save files like a pro.Also, quick personal tip: You can reverse engineer any feature of a machine by saving it and searching in the save file for the controll key of the feature.Or look for hidden blocks by searching: <Scale x="0" y="0" z="1" /> and its variations.The Great Guide on Particle GeneratorsA big with guide on a glitch-weapon class, written with scientific depth and detailednessLevitation through Vector EntanglementThis guide introduces a revolutionary building mechanic that makes building stable aircraft ridiculously easy.And if you made it all the way down here, Just buy the damn game, it costs hardly anything at all and is absolutely amazing.

content:

Early Access Review
								Besiege asks one question: What do I make now?You can build what ever you want to complete each of the challenges. It doesn't matter how ridiculous it is. All that matters is whether or not it can succeed.You can build helicopter, cars, mechs, trains, and whatever else you can think of. If you can't make it with the vanilla game's resources, there's also mods that will give you even more creative freedom in the game!Not good at creating stuff? Lacking an idea on what crazy thing to build next? The steam workshop allows you to download machines shared by others who own the game as well!The game, however, is quite demanding so you'll need to be careful of how many parts you use at any one time. A bit of a creative restriction for you there, but that's the price that we pay to have the freedom to craft whatever we want. You can also freeze and slowdown time... which is awesome.Anyway, you should totally buy this game. Also, when in doubt, a big enough explosion will clear every mission... Legit, I just strapped a bunch of bombs to a plank of wood for the transport the two iron ores mission and completed it that way...EXPLOSIONS!

Early Access Review
								In terms of graphics, art style and UI - this is the most beautiful game I've ever played. The DoF is used very well, as is the vignette and everything else to give it a very 'crisp' and 'smooth' feel.The gameplay itself is fairly simple, but with tons of possibilities. Each level can be solved in a multitude of ways, and that's just assuming you actually want to solve it and not make a trebuchet that fires smaller catapults with flamethrowers on them.The only criticism I have is that it has very few levels so far, but it's quite obvious that the developer plans to add a lot more, so take that with a grain of salt. I'm not sure if it's planned, but a level creator would be very advantageous in this game, because even with the dev releasing more levels there'll still be a demand for more, and given how most levels are constructed I can see a simple level editor being quite easy to use. 10/10 would fire a flamethrower catapult out of a trebuchet again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's basically all the mechanical features that I would have loved to have in minecraft. It plays solidly, and is very polished (for an alpha). I have noticed no game breaking bugs thus far, and the only serious inconvenience comes in the form of chugging with more complex structures. The camera controls could also use some work (there is no veritcal movement, just horizontal). So with only two minor problems I've noticed, plus a good deal of polish, I'd say that it's worth the low price as is. It reminds me a lot of Banjo Kazooie: Nuts and Bolts. There's still a lot of potential, and I hope they fully explore it. I have the feeling that they'll change the way supports work, but right now they're really convenient, and I hope they don't. The game is a sandbox, so your creativity is only limited by what tools they put in place. I'm hoping they'll give us magical blocks or weapons, such as lodestones, or staffs of lightning that you can strap to your machine. We've got the basics, and they're good. The game is solid. Here's hoping they fully explore the possibilities and don't limit themselves.

								Wow, an absolutely fantastic purchase despite being in early access. There's something deeply intriguing about siege machines and completely destroying castles and slaughtering soldiers, and in a lot of games you can pick your vehicle and go ahead in a hyper-realistic environment. With Besiege, you are stuck in a highly stylized, almost a thematically story-driven world, building your siege engines from scratch. I could see myself playing this for a LONG time. content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's presently a late-medieval (well, late enough for single-shot cannons) physics-based sandbox game.  There's an explicit sandbox mode as well as 15 goal-oriented stages (destroy X% of possible destructibles, grab items and drop them somewhere, make a vehicle and have it go through a series of checkpoints, that sort of thing).  In each, you have unlimited type to assemble something out of multiple components (right now, all parts are available in unlimited numbers every stage) within a certain volume of space; and then hit 'go' to make things happen.  Interaction during this phase comes as you activate pistons, turn steering columns, send wheels into forward and reverse, have 'grabbers' release whatever they've picked up, and so forth.The interface is guided towards you building *one* machine, since you currently need to place parts where they connect to other parts rather than arbitrarily, but you can delete the connecting parts to make separate things.  I just made an eight-vehicle force:  four fully autonomous shredders (a cube of wood with saw blades for wheels, just moves around erratically slaughtering everybody it meets); three vehicles carrying bombs (each independently steered and detonated); and one larger vehicle with blades, itself controlled independently of the car bombs.  One could have instead solved the same stage with a flying vehicle dropping bombs, or with a megamachine with multiple catapults, or maybe even a machine that carried a supply of bombs and used a claw-like arm to pick them up and drop them above wherever they needed to be.  People have already made creative and complex machines.System requirements are pretty low but if you build a very complicated machine the calculations can take a fair bit of power and slower machines might need to reduce the timescale.It's still early, and there's a lot that will be subject to change -- more content (the 15 provided stages don't take very long to complete) is obvious, more parts, finer control over parts would be good.  Notably, there's no fine-grained rotation (e.g. swiveling parts can only start swiveled at 90-degree angles, nothing more precise), and there should be more ways to cut/paste components and save/load/move individual sets of blocks to allow simpler reuse and assembly.  The ways you assemble things could certainly use some work, because while you *can* do a lot, you can get into situations where you simply need to tear something down and rebuild it entirely because you can only move all blocks at once rather than lift or shift a section.If you're looking for something to brutally challenge you on its own (rather than with self-imposed handicaps), this isn't it yet -- it probably won't take you long to 'beat'.  If you enjoy a more freeform exercise where you can take situations and see how you resolve them in goofy ways, or if you have a yen to reconstruct giant siege engines without terrifying your neighbors and getting the police called on you, this is definitely worth a look.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I normally do not ever buy Early Access games on Steam, no matter how beautiful and polished they appear. If it's so wonderful, they can complete and release the game and I'll pay for it then. But Besiege is actually beautiful and polished, and I'm glad I lost my mind for a second and bought it despite its being in Early Access. It's a clever game with lovely graphics and an active dev team, and even if all development were to stop today, it'd be good enough to be worth the price.Which is not to say that I personally love playing it. I didn't like Kerbal Space Program, and while I like this game better, it's still extremely hard for me to get into because I have trouble visualizing or imagining how a piece will act on or be acted on by the other pieces once you press "play" and set the machine into motion. I struggled with designing complex machines or machines that ran smoothly, and I mostly just blundered through the first few levels with a combination of luck and some deeply janky contraptions.But, even if you're not sure this is your type of game, I suggest giving it a spin. It's a cool little indie project that lives up to the hype. Rating: 3/55: Loved it; 4: Liked it; 3: It's OK; 2: Didn't like it; 1: Hated it

Early Access Review
								*** Update ***It's been confirmed by the developers that there will be an update shortly that will be using the Unity 5 engine. This will support multi core PhysX which will address the problems that many users are facing. As the developers are aware of the issue and are providing an imminent fix then I can now recommend the game based on the game play alone._______________________________________________Right now, it's impossible to recommend this game. This isn't due to the mechanics or game play, or even the relative lack of content so far is it is still in early access. I am referring to the terrible frame rate drops that occur once structures get to big. By 'too big' I mean anything with 50+ blocks and by 'terrible frame rate' I'm talking about a drop from 60fps down to 3. Three. 1 + 2. Uno, dos, tres. Now looking at the required system specs above they've fairly basic;Processor: 2.2Ghz Dual Core Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: 512mb Dedicated VRAMI'm runningProcessor: 2.9Ghz Quad Code i7Memory: 8GB RAMGraphics: GTX 860M with 2GB of vRAMSo it clearly isn't my set up that's causing the problem. My playtime above has lasted as long as it has as to begin with I didn't really know what I was doing and as such only really started to make large contraptions in the last half an hour or so of game play. Things may improve in future updates, but who knows, as it is this game is almost unplayable.

								Review based on ver. 0.02This game is simple, to build a machine that you can control it to complete the level.Pros:1. Game machanics is well done and gameplay is entertaining. 2. Graphics is very beautiful and stylish.3. The level design is good and gets harder when you proceed.4. The price is very reasonable and acceptable. For $6.99, you can't go wrong.Cons:1. It is Unity3d engine powered games, so the quality of dynamic shadow is a big issue.2. Pretty bad performance because of Unity engine. In level 5, my PC cannot handle it.FPS is about 5 but I am playing it on a 24-core machine with a GTX Titan...3. Lack of variation in sound effect and ambient sound. 4. Lack of some basic options in menu.Since it is on very very early stage, sound and options will be better for sure. The most problems come fromthe Unity engine not the developers. It they chose UE4 instead of Unity, they would not have these issues.But it is not their fault so I can't really blame them on this point. And still, I really enjoy playing it.With a lot of potentias, it will definitely be a great game which worth at least $14.99.So, it is still good for $6.99, and highly recommended.Update 1:Just did a quick check on both GPU and CPU usage. It seems that problem comes fromUnity engine's bad performance of CPU physics simulation. It is unoptimized for multi-core and multi-threading, when your siege machine is too complex.It still uses only 1 or 2 cores to calculate the physics which can bottleneck other hardware.Hope they could fix this in the future.

								For years, I struggled with hard drug abuse. I was hooked on various drugs until they could no longer please me, so I would move to more intense, more addictive drugs. I ended up with a crippling heroin addiction. Luckily, my wife and family were there to support me and try to get me back on track.  They put me through therapy, but I just couldn't put down the needle. My therapist suggested I find a hobby that could keep my mind off of the drugs, but every hobby I tried just couldn't supersede the addiction heroin. That is, until I found this game. Since beginning to play this game, heroin has never crossed my mind. The addiction I feel for this game has completely obliterated the addiction level I had for heroin. I never thought it was possible, but since purchasing this game, my life has gotten far worse.  My addiction to this game took everything from me. My wife, my house, my kids. Everything. So if you're looking at this game and deciding whether or not to purchase it, consider your life as it is now.  Because once you purchase this game, you can't go back. So, I countered that wall with a wall of my own, covered in armor plates and cannons.  When I fired it, it blasted the opposing wall apart and was sent flying backwards from the recoil and rolled (surprisingly harmlessly) over my vehicle, which I then drove around the flaming wreckage of the wall to destroy the rest of everything.  When I got to the iron stealing level, I dropped the vehicle entirely and went with a cannon turret which knocked the ore balls into the target zone from afar.  Since then, I've mostly been trying to find ways to complete every objective with pretty much cannons only.  What I'm saying is, buy this game and use cannons for everything.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Indie games can sometimes be hit or miss with today’s gamers, but we can’t overlook their importance for the industry.  Besiege falls into this category, but with a major twist.It’s in alpha.Now don’t get discouraged, friends.  I know what you’re thinking.  This, pay-for-an-unfinished-game-before-it-comes-out thinking that seems to be wildly popular on formats such as Steam is a silly way to run an industry.  Why should you pay for an unfinished game?  There’s a reason. Besiege is a medieval weapons building and physics simulator.  A lot to take in yes, but let me explain.  You are given multiple building materials, moving bits, and yes, crazy medieval weapons.  The current version of the game has one of five worlds open.  You are given a task in each level of the world, such as destroy a house or kill 90% of everything, and cannot move to the next level without completing the task at hand.  The fun part comes from how you do it.  There are no restrictions, and however you get the job done is up to you.  You can be simple or extravagant.  The choice is yours. Besiege presents you with a blank slate, teaming with destructive, creative potential.  Do you build a trebuchet?  Or perhaps a wall of cannons?  Maybe you just want to see how ridiculous you can get and still beat the level.  These are all possible scenarios.  Additionally, this game looks fantastic for a game in alpha.  It also plays great. And sounds great.  This game quickly makes you forget that it is in alpha.This bring me back to the original point.  Yes it is in alpha.  But does that take away from the game?  Perhaps content wise, yes, but the folks at Spiderling Games have proven their worth in the small amount available.  Rather than open a lot of the game at lower quality, the developers took the time to concentrate on one area of the game and make it represent closer to what the finished product may ultimately look like.  Because of this, the alpha version of Besiege feels complete.  The seven dollars you may have reluctantly paid for “another buggy early access game” quickly becomes worth it as you see your giant flame throwing head you modeled after Steve Buscemi’s face burn a bunch of sheep alive, although that may not be exactly the goal given to you. Did I mention the sheep?Failure is spectacular in this game and actually quite a big part of the hilarity.  The grander your killing machine the more spectacular the destruction can be if you don’t build it right.  Sometimes, you even find yourself setting yourself up for failure, just to see the results. Besiege’s incomplete state does leave you with the feeling of yearning for something more.  It is short and can seem to be unfulfilling after a while but, thankfully, the developers address this too.  Regular updates occur to Besiege with new blocks and weapons every so often, and new worlds have estimated release dates on them.  This keeps me going, and involved with the game because I know that more content will soon be added. The physical game plays well with minor problems.  One of the few is the camera.  While it is fairly easy to grasp, it can be difficult at times to move throughout the playable field which is necessary on larger missions.  Additionally, it can sometimes be cumbersome to re-map key bindings on more complicated machines, but the time you invest in this will make for a beautiful result in the long run. I have bought alpha-stage games before only to be disappointed that they never come to fruition or are simply unplayable.  Besiege is the first game i actually feel like the developers will keep adding to it until it is finished.  This, to me, is the benefit of early access gaming.  Small developers, like Spiderling Games, can take the time to make what they really want, while keeping fans interested. VERDICT? Just buy it! Ultimately, the game an early access game, but don’t let that discourage you.  For seven dollars it is an absolute BARGAIN.  There is so much creative potential, it looks fantastic, its intuitive, and it still has more content coming.  The continued playability doubled with the future release of more content makes this game extremely appealing, and should more than make up for its few shortcomings

content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								GameplayCasual sandbox physics simulator. Endless possibilities and creative freedom. Besiege offers a growing number of parts/weapons/tools at your disposal to complete a variety of challenges. Physics work believably, constructing and testing different machines is challenging. Each zone consists of one objective and the ability to construct a new machine or edit the previously successful vehicle. Simple in nature but the difficulty slowly rises as you must become more creative in your designs. One zone you might grab and carry boulders to a marker, and the next you could be constructing flying machines to take down gunships.Controls are widely customizable in terms of part functions. Camera controls are a bit awkward once you start driving/flying your machine, making it frustrating to operate. Currently includes a nice sandbox mode for testing builds. Besiege seems to be regularly updated which is a nice thing to see in an Early Access.SoundFairly absent of any noticeable music, not entirely a downside but it would help break up the silence and occasional animal/soldier sound effects.GraphicsSimplistic and charming. Environments are created on an endless plane and while these structures are constricted to a small area, they appear more like artistic renders than simply blocks waiting to fall over. Enemies and objects are minimal but beautifully crafted. Destruction works in an enjoyably fluid way, meaning each piece and part reacts accordingly once effected by another object/weapon. Visual effects like fire/smoke/sparks are mesmerizing and even more so once you slow down time using the in-game slider.Replay ValueA great deal of replay value is possible in Besiege and the increasing number of updates add new parts to tinker with. However this is largely dependent on the players creativity. Starting out it may seem a little rocky but once you familiarize yourself with the function of each part you'll begin to create more intricate machines. Each zone offers the same objective but the creative control aspect makes for an infinite number of ways to complete it.Wrapping UpCharming, challenging, and enjoyable. Easy to learn but hard to master. With a very reasonable price tag, Besiege is a solid Early Access title that is shaping up to be an incredibly worthwhile game.

								Besiege asks one question: What do I make now?You can build what ever you want to complete each of the challenges. It doesn't matter how ridiculous it is. All that matters is whether or not it can succeed.You can build helicopter, cars, mechs, trains, and whatever else you can think of. If you can't make it with the vanilla game's resources, there's also mods that will give you even more creative freedom in the game!Not good at creating stuff? Lacking an idea on what crazy thing to build next? The steam workshop allows you to download machines shared by others who own the game as well!The game, however, is quite demanding so you'll need to be careful of how many parts you use at any one time. A bit of a creative restriction for you there, but that's the price that we pay to have the freedom to craft whatever we want. You can also freeze and slowdown time... which is awesome.Anyway, you should totally buy this game. Also, when in doubt, a big enough explosion will clear every mission... Legit, I just strapped a bunch of bombs to a plank of wood for the transport the two iron ores mission and completed it that way...EXPLOSIONS!

content:
Posted: January 24
Early Access Review
								I can warmly recommend this game to anyone who likes destruction or building gamesThe trailers just show simple destruction and explosions, but there is so much more to it!With bsg. editing or buiding mods, you can enhance besiege immeasurebly:You can now build  smooth sleek creations, creating jets or monster trucks with incredible detailedness,you can change parameters to the point where reality itself starts to crumble,discovering bugs yet unknown to man, creating surreal machines.But you can also challenge yourself and build equally amazing vanilla creations wich can keep up with modded machines with ease and excelence, beating multiple Isles with one single creation consisting of just ten blocks or less.Or you can just download creations, enjoying the intricate and creatively destructive masterpieces.Just don't expect to have significant long-time challenges delivered by the game itself,you have to be able to enjoy a game without a story or many instructions to like besiege.But this is the true beauty of besiege: you can build whaterver you would like to build.You also have to keep in mind that you can't just start the game and build the most awesome creations in the entire workshop, it takes quite some time until you are a fully experienced Besiegeneer. Starting to buildA few tipsBesiege is a suprisingly complex game even though it just seems like a small buiding game you can play for a bit. That's why anyone who really wants to start building should read as much guides as you can find and seek the advice of more experienced members of the community, but probably the most important thing of all: Practice. I would describe myself as a besiege-scientist who loves to discover (hopefully) amazing bugs, and I personally use a „trick“ to build my creations: I think of besiege as a kind of alternate reality.(And yes, that might sound kind of crazy but wait!)Just like our world, it too is gowerned by strict laws wich generate a beautifull complexity, just like in the real world, you can take a close look at those laws and understand them,eventually thinking just like a inhabitant inside of the game would. And at that point, not even the sky is your limit. You can just glitch it out of your way. But hey, thats just my crazy way of playing and understanding besiege.Recommended ModsBuilding Tool mod by The Guys You DespisePrecision Building Project 2 by ITRNo Bounds Mod by ITRYou can find a site with all mods here![forum.spiderlinggames.co.uk]Recommended GuidesBesiege for BeginnersThe most basic basics.Neutex's Guide on Advanced EngineeringA guide of excelent quality, highly recommended.Advanced GlitchingRequires mods or bsg. file editingThe two guides are made by me, and yes, there is probably a bit of bias involved...-bsg.-file editing made easy- A must-watch for basically everyone, it describes bsg.-file editing in depth while being easy to understand, enabling you to edit the save files like a pro.Also, quick personal tip: You can reverse engineer any feature of a machine by saving it and searching in the save file for the controll key of the feature.Or look for hidden blocks by searching: <Scale x="0" y="0" z="1" /> and its variations.The Great Guide on Particle GeneratorsA big with guide on a glitch-weapon class, written with scientific depth and detailednessLevitation through Vector EntanglementThis guide introduces a revolutionary building mechanic that makes building stable aircraft ridiculously easy.And if you made it all the way down here, Just buy the damn game, it costs hardly anything at all and is absolutely amazing.

content:
Posted: April 14
Early Access Review
								Basically:This game is awesome. but it is not for everybody.It is the most open-ended engineering and building game in the market by a massive stretch, and when you add in modding, the possibilities are literally endless. if you are an imaginative person who loves thinking about building stuff - and whatever stuff tbh cause you are guaranteed to be able to make it - then you need this game. The levels are pretty unique and really well designed - the game is very well balanced as well (unless you mod, which is fun in other ways), and the Devs are really good at keeping the game interesting, be it with new blocks or levels, but honestly you can keep it interesting by yourself by just building more stuff. Once you really get into the game and learn how everything works, stuff gets more fun, and the more you play, the better it gets because you become a much more able engineer. This is one of the only games i can say just keeps getting better the more you play it. not to mention, the community is awesome, and some people are insane when it comes to steam workshop creations. And remember - this game is still only early access. The incoming multiplayer update is going to revolutionise the game, and undoubtedly for the better. With 95% recommended reviews and a cost of about 7 bucks, there is really no way you can go wrong. I have read some of the negative reviews, and some are outdated, but some have reasonable points, though most acknowledge it is actually a pretty good game in some way. Despite this, with 95% recommended reviews and a cost of about 5 bucks, there is really no way you can go wrong.PS: you kinda feel like the bad guy, and it is really cool to be able to not be a hero and just end up destroying everything insteadFinal judgement: Just get it.

								My first creation in this game was a small vehicle covered in cannons and flamethrowers.  It worked fine, but by the time I got to the fourth level, I needed some protection and a way to dispatch the wall in front of me.  So, I countered that wall with a wall of my own, covered in armor plates and cannons.  When I fired it, it blasted the opposing wall apart and was sent flying backwards from the recoil and rolled (surprisingly harmlessly) over my vehicle, which I then drove around the flaming wreckage of the wall to destroy the rest of everything.  When I got to the iron stealing level, I dropped the vehicle entirely and went with a cannon turret which knocked the ore balls into the target zone from afar.  Since then, I've mostly been trying to find ways to complete every objective with pretty much cannons only.  What I'm saying is, buy this game and use cannons for everything.

Early Access Review
								2 hours, one continent, and enough grinning and giggling to make me hurt.From the unforgiving physics to the suicidal sheep, I've thoroughly enjoyed every bit of this little treasure thus far! This is a very much-needed breath of creativity here in the gaming community, even amidst similar games.My first effort within the game was (almost) perfecting a catapult atop an anti-infantry engine. After 20 minutes of tinkering and testing, I finally got the arm to stop snapping. ...And instead, the entire engine was flipping over.The second major effort was building a flying bomber. ...Unfortunately, it took me roughly twenty minutes of giggling to figure out that there is currently no way to hold a bomb underneath a vehicle. 								Alright, time to list off the pros and cons.PROSCheap.WEAPONS!!!An option for blood and guts, so I can show it to my mom and not get grounded for 5 months.Killing armies. Woohoo!Killing peasants. WOOHOO!Killing farmers. WWOOOOHHOOOO!!Killing birds. WWWWOOOOOOOOHHHHOOOOOOOO!!!!Killing bulls. WWWWWWWWOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOHHHHHHHHOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!Burning houses.Blowing houses up.Smashing houses.Shredding houses.Driving through houses.Smashing castles.Blowing castles up.Driving through castle.Smashing random crap.Blowing up random crap.Driving over and through random crap.A planned multiplayer update! This might make me lose a couple hundred friends, even though I don't have that much, but who cares? Well, I sort of do.Puzzles.Use your imagination for great good fun and evil!If your imagination is as sucky as mine (which isn't possible, really), then you can get some great machines from the workshop!Change the keybinds for certain blocks!Change the blocks' strength, speed, etc.Get mods!Get skins!Physics!Okay, I cut the pros a little short, but that's because I had do do the cons as well, which take me a while to figure out. Here they are.Physics.You can't drag blocks.You can't resize blocks.Seriously. Two cons and so many pros that I can't count, but maybe it's because I never went to school. I can count to five, though! Also, to make wheels that turn, you need to put steering hinges or steering blocks before the wheels and maybe flip them to get it to work. content:

Early Access Review
								As a standalone / vanilla game I'd give this game an 8.5/10. Building is easy to start doing, and as you get more advanced possibilities of creations are endless. The levels are all amazing, and it's fun to try to rebeat all the levels with different creations. The only reason I wouldn't give the vanilla game a 10/10 is because the modding community is what makes this game a 10/10. Don't get me wrong its a ton of fun without mods, but there are completely endless possibilities with mods. I started out making catapults and cars and hovercraft and other fun stuff. But when I installed a few building mods, it opened up a whole new domain of what could be done with this game. I'm not that gifted at building myself, but I've seen some crazy stuff like transformers, sniper defense mini games, trains, super realistic functioning models of battleships, the stuff you can do in this game is jawdropping. It's worth the $8.00 just to build in vanilla, but with mods its even more of a deal.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥this game is fun.I started off not knowing what the hell I was doing. I built some horrible broken mechanical demon that couldn't even destroy the house in the first level. Until I put a bunch of cannons on it. I named it "Abomination" and left it to rot. Shortly afterwards, I created some prototype vehicles, and didn't get very far with those either. At this point, I was getting bored. Then I had an idea.Cannons. Many, many, many cannons. Filling up the entire frame of the construct, low and high, fit to tear apart almost any building that stood in my way. My first true creation. I christened it 'Godslayer'. Over a short period of time, I worked to improve it. Godslayer V2 had wheels and suspension, V3 had spikes, blades, and even more cannons. V4 was fitted with plows and flamethrowers, but sacrificed some of the raw cannonpower, and V5, the current version, had reduced recoil and two large catapults containing bombs at the back. A true master piece in my eyes. And yet, I had grown tired of it. As my experience with the game grew, so did my need for more complex machinery.And so I sought to create more machines. At this stage I made something called 'Sorta works'. I don't know what it is or what I was attempting to make, but I was not pleased with the outcome. After that, I made a prototype Ballista, which was made to fire a long block of wood with a spike at the front towards the target. It only worked half the time, so I abandoned it and got to work on something a touch more complex.It started with nothing but a large array of pistons in a line with a spike on the end, which would extend forwards and poke whatever was infront of it. I was pleased with it, but I saw plenty of room for improvement. Version 2 had wheels, a cannon, and a contractable spring to stabilize the pistons. V3 had a working catapult and even more cannons, aligned so that they would reach over cannons in front when the pistons were active. The current version, V4, made the catapult piston based so that its range could be altered, cannons were added and keybindings were altered to make the machine easier and more convinient to use, and spinning blades were added to the front to evicerate whoever decides to stand in front of it. This unstoppable amalgamation of wood and steel proceeded to tear apart buildings, evicerate armies, and flatten fortresses with relative ease. It isn't perfect or impressive by any means, but it is a creation that I am proud of, and may continue to build upon. Truly, this game is fantastic. Even with the limited resources there is a huge variety of things to create. The updates may come slowly, but they will come. Buy it while it's cheap so you can get to destroying buildings with a phallus-shaped mechanical monstrosity. Which I have also done.
